author: Sharon
title: Chez Sonenblumenkrantz
post_content: Warning: No creativity to be found here.I want to let my readers (True - I doubt that my readership has increased from 0 to 2 in the past hour. But humor me as I pretend.) know that I am not a creative cook. I am a scientist, and can (sometimes) follow instructions very well. So I have invested in some good cookbooks and spend a lot of time scouring recipes on the internet. I will share with you which recipes I thought came out well and which did not. And I will tell you where they came from. Because I can almost guarantee that they were not creations of mine!Dinner on Saturday night was motivated by a few things. First, we receive our weekly produce box on Thursdays from Moore Farms and Friends. Because the produce tends to be quite diverse and often new to me, I try explore recipes and cook some of it up over the weekend. This week, among other things, we had a bunch of Komastuna and 2 pounds of mixed roots (including PURPLE potatoes… who knew!). Second, we had dinner at Soto Soto on Friday night. The food was absolutely excellent. The sort of food that reminds me why I love food so much. (Thanks to the husband’s boss for taking us there for the annual holiday party!) Perhaps someone who is better with words can help me to explain the experience of taking a bite of simple, yet perfectly flavored, beautifully fragrant food. You just close your eyes, take a small bite and sit back and enjoy. Anyway, the cuisine was Italian, and the husband had some fabulously done polenta along side his duck. (Of course it quacks). Note: Since this is technically the husband’s blog too, I think "the husband" is too impersonal. I will call him J from now on.This random assortment of motivations led to a dinner of roasted roots, sautéed Komastuna, and baked polenta. An odd mix, but the range of colors speaks to how nutrient-dense the meal must have been.I didn’t take a picture this time, but check out the weekly newsletter from Moore Farms and Friends for the roasted roots. We used their recipe (toss the diced roots in olive oil with salt and pepper) plus a few additions. We added a handful of shallots (whole), some sprigs of rosemary from the remains of our garden and a bit of thyme. Once the roots were cooking, I realized I hadn’t started the polenta and had no clue how the timing of the meal was going to work out. There’s usually one point during each meal that I become totally overwhelmed with the mess I’ve made (I'll have to post pictures one day - I make a serious mess while cooking), the pile of dirty dishes, and the three things that inevitably need to be stirred, tasted and turned at the same time. Often that’s when J will come to the rescue. So J helped get things prepped while I tried to figure out how to cook the polenta.We’ve tried making polenta once before – we cooked it for the full 30 minutes on the stove (stirring, stirring, stirring… keep that husband stirring) and ended up with a thick, coagulated, not-so-tasty block. But at Soto Soto, J’s polenta was almost creamy on the inside and nice and crunchy on the outside. My brief internet search turned up many polenta recipes, but none were described as such. So we cooked it according to the recipe on the package (6 cups water, 2 cups polenta, some salt), for somewhere between 5 and 10 minutes, stirring continuously. When it had the consistency of thick cereal with no visible liquid, but was still far from paste, we poured it into a pyrex baking dish and let it sit for a few minutes. I brushed the top with melted butter and stuck it in the oven with the roots. At about 10 minutes the roots were done so I dropped the oven temperature to 350, added the shredded parmesan that I had forgotten about earlier in the process, and cooked for another 10 minutes. At 20 minutes it wasn’t quite crunchy enough, so I stuck it under the broiler for 2 minutes. The cheese bubbled up nicely and left a slightly browned, crisp top.Meanwhile… the sautéed Komatsuna. We had prepared it in the past sautéed on its own, as well as served with Asian Turnip Greens. This time we wanted to try something different. The recipe adds a considerable amount basil at the end of the cooking process and sounded intriguing. Sadly, this was one of the times where I sort of forgot to follow the instructions. The greens were supposed to be steamed for a few minutes, not continuously sautéed. Whoops. And when I added the basil it turned black. I know that cutting into wet basil causes it to turn, but these were fresh, intact basil leaves. Perhaps the heat was too high (not off like it was supposed to be according to the recipe) and it caused the cellular structure to break down? This is a question for AB! Either way, I doubt we’ll be trying this recipe again.The verdict:The roasted roots were both attractive and tasty. J loved the strong horseradish-like aromas and tastes from some of the roots. These were a success. And believe it or not, the polenta turned out really well, and without all of the hard work I was expecting. We’ll definitely be using that “recipe” again.  I will also  be eating it for the rest of the week because there were tons of leftovers. As for the Komastuna, I learned (as I often do) that simplicity is good. And follow instructions.

author: Robin
title: The Hard Cell
post_content: Konami, is that you?Women in videogames tend to be significantly more buxom, pouty, and provocatively dressed than the majority of their real life counterparts. You don't need to be a genius to work out why that is. Most gamers are men. Most men enjoy looking at buxom, pouty, scantily clad women. You'd be hard pressed to find a woman character in a videogame who doesn't flaunt her sexuality to some degree. It's all a matter of degrees though. Some games can maintain a modicum of subtlety and class in this regard, even going so far as properly contextualising the character's behaviour and motivation within the plot (such as Silent Hill 2's Maria, or Metal Gear Solid 3's Eva).On the other hand, there are games that seek to do none of this, offering shameless titillation without concern for plot, or even decent gameplay. In Japan, this kind of game is a genre unto itself. Japanese budget game publisher D3 has released a whole slew of games centred around women in bikinis doing stuff. Fighting, snowboarding, posing, playing mahjong, dismembering zombies, competing in wacky game-shows, growing to enormous size and crushing cities godzilla-style, etc. It's an established and accepted genre in Japan.In the Western world, games like these have never really taken off. The notable exception is Tecmo's Dead or Alive: Xtreme Beach Volleyball (XBox) which was less of a volleyball game, and more of a boob-simulator. Tecmo's DOA fighting-game franchise was always better known for its cast of busty women and jiggle-dynamics than its core gameplay. Cashing in on this, Tecmo saw fit to release a game focussed on the girls of DOA bouncing around in swimsuits. It sold massive numbers all over the world, not because its target-market wanted to play volleyball, but because they wanted to see these virtual girls jiggling about in increasingly skimpy bikinis. Ironically, DOA:XBV is, in my opinion, one of the 'girliest' games ever made. Behind the eye-candy, the game is really all about shopping for outfits and accessorizing.All this pre-amble brings me to the latest wrestling game from Konami. "The first and only all-women's wrestling game on any platform": Rumble Roses (PS2). Konami, the very same company that gave the world the Silent Hill and Metal Gear games, has shockingly released the new pinnacle in boob-powered videogames. Make no mistake - Rumble Roses hits the player over the head with overt T & A like no other game I've ever seen. It's all presented in a fairly light-hearted manner with no nudity whatsoever, and yet it seems more confronting than ever due to the lifelike animation. The fact is that in games that bother to animate breasts, they're typically more reminiscent of large globes of weightless jelly than any real body parts. Not so in Rumble Roses - its evident that a lot of time was spent perfecting the physics and motion of the Roses' bodies, such that they move, bounce and, dare I say it, sag in a very weighty and realistic fashion. And then there are the mud matches - that's right: women in bikins wrestling in mud. Another dubious first for videogames.I asked myself how Konami could stoop so low as to produce one of these tacky pervert games that sacrifices gameplay and production values for the sake of cheap smut. Well, hang on a minute. It may look like a duck, but it doesn't necessarily quack like a duck. Konami developed this game in conjunction with Yukes, the undisputed masters of wrestling game design. Despite my view that (and I may be struck down for saying this) wrestling games don't rank too highly up the foodchain, I have to admit the gameplay mechanics of Rumble Roses are solid. It's slightly less complex than Yukes' Smackdown games but is just as well balanced and no doubt was simplified to make it more accessible and fun. Performing the usual wrestling moves fills meters, alowing each character to execute special killer, lethal and humiliation moves. Some of these are truly spectacular. The production values are actually very high; the graphics engine is impressive and the wrestling animation and motion capture work is top notch. There is actually a plot. A ridiculous one, to be sure, involving the use of a legendary dead wrestler's DNA in an evil scheme to produce cyborgs, but its better than nothing. Each character has a storyline, played out in cutscenes between matches. Each character also has an unlockable alter-ego, which is more than just a mere palette-swap or alternate costume. The alter-egos have their own distinct personalities and storylines. The voice acting is dire, but the soundtrack is very good, from the rocking cover of David Lee Roth's Yankee Rose, to new tracks from Konami's respected composer Akira Yamaoka. This game has Konami written all over it, from the character design, to the music and the billboards throughout the game promoting other Konami franchises.Konami are not ashamed. Perhaps they shouldn't be. While they have produced an outrageously blatent T &amp; A game, they have also made the first game of this type that actually plays well and is technically a quality production in almost every respect (attrocious voice acting aside).Is it a great game? Certainly not.Is it a good game? Yes, strangely enough it is.Will it succeed? It has the potential to sell bucketloads.Will it help change the popular perception of gamers as sexually frustrated geeks who need to get out more? No.Rumble Roses will be released in Australia this Friday.

author: editor
title: I Am Not That Important
post_content: I still love myself.I feel like the Buddha sitting under the tree, determined to figure things out to help enlighten the world.I feel like Carl Jung writing in his Red Book but hiding it so the world could only see his brilliant findings.I feel like Eckhart Tolle when he was young and isolated himself so that he could figure out why he existed.Do you get it?THE most brilliant minds, whose thoughts shaped our culture and history are all nutcases who had to claw their way out of their own personal hell in order to create a philosophy of healing.ALL OF THEM!So don't feel bad for me or sorry for me or grow weary of me.Rejoice as I enter the dark places, as I give up on hopes, as I walk away from socially constructed thinking. I am NOT normal. But neither are the greatest minds in history.I do not fit in, but neither did anyone who paved the way for progress.I am in a position, in THIS position, of darkness and complete openness, openly sharing my evolution, even if it makes me look stupid. I'm doing it because it heals me and it will heal you.I am the Buddha.I am the Red Book.I am the New Earth.Just a little ghetto with it and just a little bit sexy.But wait and see what this time, this experience, births.I can't WAIT to see!

author: kiki
title: TORI WEEKEND!!!
post_content: My favorite phrase that is posted in the room where I have a first aid and CPR class:  "Don't act a fool in the pool."  It's so...poetic and...refined...Well, it's official. I think enough time has passed for me to be able to say this with certainty: this semester SUCKS! I was hoping that with time it would get better, but a month has passed. It's still boring. My schedule is unbelievably boring. Basically, I just sit in the back of classrooms and play games on my iPod or read, and I HAVE to go to class because of the strict attendance policy at the school. So I get my entertainment pack together, much like I do when I'm getting ready to go to church, so the hours of boredom will pass without incident.The thing that really sucks about the boring schedule is that it has caused me to be apathetic regarding how well I do in these classes. Like, this morning, I had a test, and I didn't even study for it. The material was so boring that my choices were to die from boredom or to not make an A on the test. I chose to not make an A, so I took the most boring test in the world this morning, actually finished it, and scored 80%. And I'm happy with that. I got a B on my chemistry test 2 weeks ago, and I'm happy with that.Another strange consequence of having a boring schedule is that my favorite class is chemistry lab, taught by my male arch-nemesis of 2005. I know...shocker! He's actually being very nice this semester. I mean, he still rips people's heads off and shoves them down their throat if they come in late to class, but in lab, he's cordial. He doesn't make me feel stupid when I mess things up. When I ask questions in class, he's more than eager to answer them. He's the exact opposite of what he was last semester, unless you're late for class. Don't even try that. Just don't. I've seen him make grown men cry. Anyway, I was like the star of the class last night. And he said I was "charming him" because asking questions meant that I had read the lecture before going to class. I'm not really out to charm that man, but I'm open to any methods of not succumbing to the desire to cry in front of him.

author: Call to Worship
title: Verse for Tuesday
post_content: 1 Kings 3:10 The Lord was pleased that Solomon had asked for this. 11 So God said to him, “Since you have asked﻿ for this and not for long life or wealth for yourself, nor have asked for the death of your enemies but for discernment﻿ in administering justice, 12 I will do what you have asked. I will give you a wise ﻿and discerning heart, so that there will never have been anyone like you, nor will there ever be. 13 Moreover, I will give you what you have not﻿ asked for—both wealth and honor﻿-so that in your lifetime you will have no equal﻿ among kings. 14 And if you walk﻿ in obedience to me and keep my decrees and commands as David your father did, I will give you a long life.”  If you can ask God for anything, what would ask for?  Solomon asked for wisdom... God gave him more than he expected.

author: emma
title: Race Report: Lake Stevens 70.3
post_content: The Denver Rock 'n Roll Marathon is a little over a month away!&nbsp; These next two weeks are the final build phase, culminating with a 21-Mile run.&nbsp; My coaches noted that this is the time to prioritize running and suggested we do whatever is necessary to make sure we get every training run in.&nbsp; It was recommended that we do things like write our work-outs down in our calendar and lay out our running clothes...anything that minimizes the amount of effort it takes to get to the work-out.&nbsp; It reminded me of something Bobby McGee said during his talk last spring: the athletes that have the most success aren't necessarily the most talented, but they are the most well-organized.So...I thought laying out my running clothes would be a good idea, too.&nbsp; Every time I go for a run, I either just woke up, or just got home from work and have 5-10 minutes to change and get out the door to meet my group.&nbsp; My coach probably meant lay clothes out each day, but I don't trust myself to remember to keep doing that.&nbsp; Instead, I just gathered together a bunch of complete running outfits and other running gear and tossed them in a laundry basket so I can grab-and-go without having to rifle through drawers or piles of clean laundry.&nbsp; (I've been averaging about 5 minutes a day just looking for two matching socks!&nbsp; Ridiculous!)I also have some Lentil Soup simmering in the Crock-Pot so I'll have some easy healthy meals on hand.&nbsp; Hopefully it turns out well!Happy Fall!

author: Meenakshi
title: Restaurants - Cafe Escadrille - Italian ( Burlington, MA)
post_content: June 2004 saw me in London for a customer conference. We tried the Blue Elephant Restaurant then...there were a lot of groans of dismay from folks as most people did not seem to enjoy Thai food. I love spicy food so I had no complaints.As I strolled through the restaurant it became obvious that much time and money has been poured into creating the exotic ambiance, which seems to cleverly cater just as much for romantic couples as it does for large upmarket office crowds.I had a cocktail called - Miss Siam which iis basically Coconut flesh, Coconut water, Skyy vanilla, Passion fruit liqueur. It was good.Having studied the extensive menu for ten minutes and still not chosen, the group decided to opt for the Royal Thai Banquet with soup (£39 per person), washed down by a reasonably priced bottle of Pinot Blanc and Merlot. And we were not disappointed by our choice. Starters included the regular mixture of Paper Prawns, Fish Cakes, Dim Sum, Satay and Spring rolls followed by a beautifully spicy Tom Yum soup. However, I would have liked slightly more time to digest the starters so that I could fully appreciate the six main courses; this banquet really is not for those with a small appetite! The Emerald Chicken and Green Curry really stood out for me, as well as the Ped Makaram, tender duck slices with a tamarind sauce. The Fresh Black Pepper Tiger Prawn were tender and delicious but the lamb Massaman was strictly OK.By the time the desserts arrived, I was filled to the brim! However I felt I had had a truly wonderful dining experience, and look forward to my next trip to the Blue Elephant. I know my travel companions from the U.S would beg to differ ;)

author: ChemRifle
title: It's still legal tender dammit
post_content: Wow. 5 months since I've been here. Quite a bit has changed in the last 5 months, that's for goddamn sure.Well, I've been at work officially for over a year now, and I'm still not insane! While Christmas time was fairly hectic, it certainly was survivable, although unpleasant. I suppose the only thing I learned from it is just how goddamn dumb Christmas really is. There were days where I'd accumulate $6000 in my register alone. That's almost a thousand dollars an hour from customers who shouldn't be spending that much and who I doubt have the money anyway. Thanks to the advent of credit cards, it's never been easier to spend money that you don't have! I mean shit, take that $500 of clothes and instead of feeling happy that you spent your money, give it to a family who would be happy to have it in the first place.money-spending+items doesn't equal happiness. Pretty simple really.Anyway, while I used to hate pretty much everyone at work, I'm on good terms with each and every one of them. This Christmas took out the two main targets for some reason, and as such, work is actually pretty cool now. Aside from the puny amount of shifts I've been getting lately, but that's a symptom of the moarket and not the atmosphere. At least I hope.

author: Oliver
title: A pic of me
post_content: Well, I finished fourth but because of the same thing. I started second this time then had an awful start. Further in the back, though, two karts locked wheels, and on went flying. It was the number 66 of Kyle Fittro. His kart started to do back flips through the air after he fell out from the initial contact. He had a scraped wrist but other than that he was fine. When the red flags started flying, the three karts in front of me kept on racing. I decided to slow down since it was a red flag and while that happened some of the more stupid kids decided to pass everyone. It took about ten minutes to get everything figured out. Once we started up again I fell back to third. One lap later I got passed on the straight. There was some kid who kept on trying to pass me on the straight but never could do it. I finished fourth in the heat race. After everyone else finished their heat races it was time for the mains. I had, for once, a great start for my main, still in fourth, but catching up to the guy infront of me. I was much faster than everyone in the infield, but once I got to the straight my engine let me down. After a while they still pulled away and I wasn't in their draft. I could of swore the was the number 61 of Matt Jackson trying to pass me but after the race my dad told me that he was actually pretty far back. I had to settle for fourth, which is still great. It was my fifth straight trophy. I can't wait until next race.

author: The Jackal Diaries
title: It Moves!
post_content: I felt the baby for the first time on Friday (2/24 18weeks 2days) . I had read some time ago that the baby would move away from a flashlight. I stretched out on the couch and flashed the light on each side of my belly. I could feel a fluttering in my lower tummy. I've felt it before, but just didn't know that it was the baby.Kevin tried to feel it, but I think he pushes too hard. He also thought I was kind of traumatizing the baby.The batteries ran out of the flashlight on Sunday night.

title: fake fake fakity fake fake
post_content: Her lips turned up.  And in an instant I felt like I was looking at death itself.  I was staring down impurity, fucking hatred, everything wrong with everything right.  And in an instant I knew, portent it; this was the mortal coil.  Her lips creeped higher and higher up until I heard the ripping of flesh.  My eyes fluttered closed; I didn't want to see, didn't want to know.  I could hear the things that held the skin to the muscle, held the muscle to the bones, veins, tendons, it was all ripping away, curling inside itself. The sound of cloth ripping was too much, I squeezed my eyes together tighter.  Ground the enamel of my teeth away.  Pressure hit my body, a wave of nothing, wind almost.  She was gone.  There wasn't anything left, except the chair in which she sat, pulled out slightly. Tilted just to the left.

author: tempdisplaced
title: Reality Show?
post_content: It's been a weekend of changeable weather - breezy, sending the clouds by at a good clip, breaking them up so the sunshine can actually penetrate for short burts, then packing in with a solid rain shower for a few minutes. And the wind has changed direction, now coming from the North which is nippy, but still allowing the weather to change. Way more fun than watching paint dry...Best of all, the February golds, or whatever they're called, have finally bloomed. Been waiting for days for them to get going, sitting curled up in their pistol shapes with just the hint of yellow coming through the outer green covering. But finally, they've opened their little yellow daffodil heads to say that Life isn't always gray and overcast. Hurray.And an update: a few minutes after originally posting this entry, snow is falling, from the North of course, but giant flakes. Hope the daffs don't mind!

author: Jack, Jody and Keb-Mo Jessee
title: Third Grade
post_content: Every kid today knows about the Xbox, PS2, and GameCube.  Mine is no exception he has all three.  Today the dog (Keb-Mo) learned more about these gadgets than he would have liked.  Keb is a 126lb dog that lives inside with us.  He is a big baby, loves everyone and would not hurt a fly, but sometimes I get tied up at work and can not get free to walk him like I should.  He has grown acustomed to controlling his bladder very well, but every so often he does it in the house.  Today I came in early but I got a telephone call.  Keb was doing his get me out to pee dance, but I could not get off of the telephone call.  He left the room, shortly there after I heard a loud explosion type of sound, the dog flew through the air, hit the wall, and let out a blood curling yelp.  As I ran to see what had happened it was very clear.  Since he had to go very badly and I did not take him out he went to the nearist room, my sons, and pee'ed on the TV.  He did it on the side where the air vents are.  Needless to say he shorted out the tv and he got a very big shock.  The dog is alright, eventhough he may be even better potty trained than before.  The TV is fried, and I am sure Wal-Mart will not trade it for a new one.  Oh well no harm just one TV, and Keb Mo got a real leson in electricity.

ترسيم : ناليد، آه مى : كنيد، مى : در حالى كه فقط ندبه مىها از جبن و فرومايگىآكنده است، سستى : رسد، دل : نماييد؟ بوى پوسيدگى از زندگى به مشام مى : مىهاى نرمى به هم بسته است... شما در اين : ها را با رشته : و تنبلى خردها را از كار بازداشته و دستمقدار و قابل ترحم هستيد! چه : آوريد؟ چقدر شما كوچك و بى : نظمى و هرج و مرج و زبونى چه مى : بىاندازه نظاير شما زياد است! اى كاش يك آدم خشن و دوست داشتنى كه قلب سوزان و مغز توانايىشد كه در اين تنگناى ننگ آور سكوت، : شد كه محيط بر همه چيز بود! چه مى : داشت پيدا مى : مىهاى متحرك : ه اين مرده i وار آنها ارواح تحقير شد : شد و ضربات ناقوس : هاى معجزآسايى شنيده مى : گفتهآورد... : مى : را به لرزه درآيد كدام يك در وجود : كردم. يادم نمى : ها مدتى سكوت كرد. من به او نگاه نمى : بعد از اين حرفمن بيشتر بود: وحشت يا خجلت؟توانى به من بگويى؟ : ه او شنيده شد: چه مى i سؤال خونسردان١٣جواب دادم: هيچ!و از نو سكوت حكمفرما شد.— پس حالا چطور زندگى خواهى كرد؟دانم. : — نمىچه خواهى گفت؟ : —سكوت كردم.تر از سكوت نيست!... : هيچ كارى عاقلانه : —خنديد كه گويى : اش بلند شد. چنان بالذت مى : مكث دردناكى نمود و به دنبال آن صداى خندههi مدتها است فرصت چنين خنديدن راحت و مطبوعى را پيدا نكرده است. ولى دل من از اين خندگريست. : لعنتى خون مىكنى؟ : معلم زندگانى؟ تويى كه به اين آسانى دست و پايت را گم مى : — هه هه هه! اين تو هستى —هايى مثل تو كه پير به دنيا : كنم حالا فهميدى من كى هستم؟ هه هه هه ... هر كدام از جوان : فكر مىشدند. : باختند و سراسيمه مى : كردند، همينطور مانند تو خود را مى : اند اگر با من سر و كار پيدا مى : آمدهفقط آن كسى ممكن است در مقابل وجدان خود نلرزد كه خود را در زره دروغ و وقاحت و بى شرمىپوشانده باشد. توانايى تو به قدرى كم است كه فقط مشتى براى سقوطت كافى ست! حرف بزن!چيزى بگو كه ترا در مقابل من تبرئه كند. آنچه گفتم تكذيب كن، جانت را از چنگال خجلت و درد رهاكن! لااقل براى يك دقيقه هم شده قوى باش، به خودت اطمينان داشته باش تا آنچه را كه من به توام پس بگيرم و در جلوى تو سر تعظيم فرود بياورم ... قدرت روحى خودت را نشان بده تا به : نسبت دادهام : معلمى تو اعتراف كنم! من احتياج به معلم دارم. چون انسان هستم. زندگى را در تاريكى، گم كردهجويم. راه را به : و راه رستگارى به سوى روشنايى، به طرف حقيقت و زيبايى، به سمت زندگى نوين را مىاعتنايى : من نشان بده! من انسان هستم. به من كينه ورزى كن، بزن، ولى در عوض مرا از اين لجن زار بىخواهم بهتر از آنچه هستم باشم! چكار كنم؟ به من بياموز! : به زندگى بيرون بكش! من مىفكر مى كردم: آيا انجام تقاضايى كه اين مرد به خود حق داده و پيش پاى من نهاده براى منگردد. بايستى راه : شود، تاريكى شك و ترديد بر افكار مردم چيره مى : مقدور است؟ زندگى خاموش مىبينم. نبايد براى خوشبختى كوشش : خروج را پيدا كرد. راه كدام است؟ من فقط يك راه بيشتر نمىكرد. احتياجى به خوشبختى نيست! معناى زندگى در خوشبختى نيست و رضامندى از خود، انسانهاست. مفهوم واقعى زندگى در : را ارضا نمى كند، زيرا بدون شك، مقام انسان خيلى والاتر از اينزيبايى و نيروى تلاش به سوى هدف است و هستى در هر لحظه بايد هدفى بس عالى داشتهه زندگى كه در آن همه چيز تا اين اندازه i باشد. اين امر ممكن است ولى نه در چهارچوب كهنه و فرسودمحدود شده و آزادى روح و فكر انسان در تنگنا قرار گرفته است...اى كرد ولى اين بار خيلى آرام، مثل خنديدن كسى كه فكر بر احساسش غلبه كرده : از نو خندهاست.اند و تا چه اندازه آثار كمى از خود به يادگار گذارده اند! چرا بايد : — چه مردم زيادى در دنيا بودهاندازه تحريك : فرستيم، زيرا حسادت ما را نسبت به خود بى : اين طور باشد؟ اما ما به گذشته لعنت مىمى كند، زيرا امروزه چنين مردمى كه پس از مرگ خود اثر پرارزشى بجاى گذارند اصلاً وجود ندارند.شود. : رود و به حيوان بدل مى : كند. به خواب مى : رود ... هيچكس هم او را بيدار نمى : انسان به خواب مى١٤براى او تازيانه وبه دنبال ضرباتِ آن نوازش آتشين و با حرارت عشق لازم است. از زدن او بيم نداشتهكند، و آن را به عنوان استحقاق : باش. چون اگر تو او را دوست بدارى و بزنى معنى ضربات تو را درك مىپذيرد. وقتى هم كه احساس درد نمود و از خود خجالت كشيد با حرارت نوازشش كن. دوباره جان : مىها و فساد فكرى خود دچار : گيرد... مردم هنوز طفل هستند با اينكه گاهگاهى ما را از تبهكارى : مىه روحى نيازمندند... i كنند ولى هميشه به محبت و كوشش دايم و پيگير براى غذاى سالم و تاز : حيرت مىتوانى مردم را دوست بدارى؟ : آيا مىبا ترديد سؤال او را تكرار كردم:دانم آيا مردم را دوست دارم يا نه! بايد صميمى : — مردم را دوست بدارم؟ راستى خود من هم نمىدانم. كيست كه با خود بگويد: بله من مردم را دوست دارم! انسانى كه دقيقاً به : و صادق بود: نمىها روى اين سؤال فكر : مدت « دوست دارم » نگرد قبل از اينكه جواب داده بگويد : درون خويش مىها از ما دور هستند. : دانند كه نزديكان ما فرسنگ : كند. همه مى : مىروم. : فهمم... و مى : اينكه تو حرف بزنى منظورت را مى : اى؟ اهميتى ندارد. بى : تو سكوت كرده : —بآهستگى پرسيدم: به همين زودى. چون آن اندازه كه من براى خودم وحشتناك شده بودم اوبراى من نبود.هم پيش تو خواهم آمد. منتظر باش. : روم، ولى باز : بله، مى : —و رفت.اى بود و محو شد... : چه جور رفت؟ متوجه نشدم. بسرعت و بدون صدا رفت مثل اينكه سايهكردم و متوجه : من باز هم مدتى روى نيمكت درون باغ نشستم. سرماى بيرون را احساس نمىدرخشد. : ها مى : ه درخت i هاى يخ بست : ه آن بگرمى در روى شاخه i نبودم كه خورشيد طلوع كرده و اشعتابيد و تماشاى اين زمين كهنسال : اعتنايى مى : ه روز روشن و خورشيدى كه مانند هميشه با بى i مشاهدزند، برايم شگفت انگيز و : ه خورشيد برق مى i و فرتوتى كه پوشاك برفى در برگرفته بود و در زير اشعجالب شده بود.

author: Robert
title: Bobby's Hits
post_content: The key to success is not what you do, it is how you feel about what you are doing. It is possible to take a simple idea and create a huge success. We think people who accomplish this work hard or have others to support them. We believe they are smarter, richer or in some way more endowed than we are. What we cannot see and do not measure is people's attitudes about what they do. Success begins with a positive attitude; it is the most valuable asset we may own. The people at the top did not fall there. They were willing to do whatever it took, taking the ups and the downs, asking for what they really wanted and staying focused until they got it. Success is not bought or inherited. It is a product of what we put out. Success begins with a good feeling about where we are and a positive attitude about where we want to be.

author: cindel ann
title: I Am Colorblind
post_content: HAPPY SINGLE AWARENESS DAY!!!!!!!!!!!hehe...I stole that from Ms. Becker....I think its hilarious and totally true, I am glad that I have grown up alittle and that I didn't have to make Valentines, I have to thank Shane, Deanna, and Mandy for your lovely cards, they made me happy although I didn't really show it, you know when you only get 3 1/2 hours of sleep it sucks.  I really didn't show much of anything today.  I, right now, am listening to sappy non love songs to make myself feel better, or maybe I just need to make myself sleepy, all of a sudden I am really thirsty...*stomps off to get some refreshing beverage* ok now I am back, so today I was totally tired and DK decided that since we were in quartets he wanted us to get up and sing, row by row, to see if we knew our pitches for John the Revelator, thank god, row 1 did ok.  I wasn't really paying attention to the other rows...so...I was daydreaming off in my own little world...sad but true, becuase I was thinking about going to work tomorrow....I absoulutely do not want to go....at all....thats being truthful for the first time ever, all the other times I was just saying it, but I really do not want to...I might cry right now, nothing is going right there, I am so just...not myself...I don't talk, and if I do, its only usually to the cashiers, because everyone treats me different...I still really like this guy at work and I don't know how I am going to talk to him tomorrow, it will be the first time we have worked together in awhile, and I am scared, and shy and I am definitly not going to know what to say.  Some things changed between us, and I grew apart and that makes me sad.  I got hurt, because I was naive and I aim to change that, I am not a stupid young child anymore, and no one is going to push me around and play with my emotions...no work relationships...AT ALL....I don't care who it is, I don't care if they like me, becuase I am moving I don't need to get into a stupid serious relationship...guys are dumb...really they are...I hate Valentines Day....I really do....so yeah going to work tomorrow and closing, not really looking forward to it, becuase I have to work with a whole bunch of guys...that I don't like anymore, well I like some of them as friends...and only that *I have to start saying that to myself, so I can believe it later on*well I really don't need to depress myself any longer and I don't want to bore any of you longer than I have to so, hope you all had a great day carrying around those dumb roses...they will all be dead in a couple of days anyway...mwahahahahahahahah...have I mentioned I hate Valentines Day?

author: Caroline
title: More than Others
post_content: Simple thoughts for a simple mind. First off it's summer. The trees have grown and are now green as a breath of the summer before everything aged. It's still spring to my family, but spring is perhaps the least favorite of all my seasons. I love how everything comes back, but my impatiance for waiting sometimes gets the best of me. when the trees have grown their buds, and shade can be cast by their leaves, then it's summer. It's only spring when the all the trees are budding. Flowers are always pre-mature in my mind. As the scouts to spring they bring hope that life will come again, but at some point are snowed on. My true memory of summer are the hot days on the lake, sailing in yet another regatta that my father made me do. Sliding my hand through the warm water I watch the path of air and fingers cut through something very much tangable, and yet not even real. At the moment clouds cover the sky, the potentail of rain exsists, but in this dry climate without the smell of ozone there's all but a small chance of rain.

author: B-Man
title: Seth-A-Nova
post_content: Well, we've got D.J., Lindsay, Zach, and Alex!  Each of them invading NewPort in their own little way!  D.J. has gotten a hold of the sobby and vulnerable Marissa, Lindsay has brought fun into Ryan's life, Zach has been keeping Summer Vibing on High Frequencies, and Alex is taking control of Seth(who actually has been needing someone to do that for a while!)!  So how do you all feel about "The New Kids On The Block?"  Like'em or Hate'em, seems that they will be around for a while!  But I feel as if there is something in each of these characters that hasn't been let out yet!  We have Zach, who seems to be the perfect guy but most of the time if someone is too good to be true they usually are!  Same with the other's really, there is no way they could be exactly what Ryan, Marrissa, Seth, and Summer need without having luggage!  I mean this is "NewPort" we are talking about!  so if you all have any hunches or anything just post a comment and let everyone know what you think about the "Move In" by "The New Kids On The Block"!  Exactly what the Doctor ordered, or trouble just beyond the horizon!?   B-Man Out!   "I Love The Vegas"&nbsp;

author: Anupam Jain
title: The Trajectory of Thought - 26/09/2004
post_content: Well except that this time there is no one bullying me into anything! Jill knows I can't write under pressure, and I hope I have driven the point sufficiently straightly home by obstinately refusing to add even a single byte of my written voice to this blog, over a period spanning approximately two years, without having felt even the slightest twinge of shame. I have held out against everything ranging from minor threats to major bouts of unconcern, never wavering. But today things change. Starting today I am going to write 500-ish words a day-ish and at the bidding of my own free will.Wow, that's 118 words already till the dot at the end of this line.Today I shall introduce myself, remaining as superficial as possible. No Sir! No soul searching for me! What I write will, I hope, set the pace of things to come.Mahesh was astounded. Mahesh was stunned. Mahesh brandished a Tommy Gun - Ed. Twenty seven shots were fired into the silent night, as four of the five bulky torsos, attached to swaying, knife wielding limbs, making threatening gestures, were neatly chopped into quarts. It was dark and quite. Mahesh was shocked. Mahesh dropped the gun and it fell to the ground making disagreeing noises. Mahesh began to run. It was time for dinner.Dinner begins at half past eight. The house is clean and brightly lit. Soft music is floating in the air. Mahesh is seated at the head of the table. The little kid sits directly opposite him but does not look at Mahesh. He is looking over his right shoulder at a Television screen. There is soup and peas mixed together on the table. The little kid gets up and changes the channel on the television. The bright lights suddenly change character. Dark rock music engulfs the room. The lights dance around the room in rapidly changing hues. There is no peace on earth, even inside of a man’s house. There is a shotgun on the table - Dark, solid and comforting. Mahesh squeezes his arms around the shotgun and it goes off. There is silence once more. The infernal music is still playing.The little kid was stunned. There was blood in his soup and there was blood on the Television screen. He ran out of the room screaming for help. Two strong bulky hands descended on him at the door and the screaming stopped almost immediately. The fifth had found him. Things were never easy for Mahesh. He always had to fight for his life, but he had always won. Mahesh was invincible and things would remain the same today. He grabbed the right hand of the fifth and spun him around. There was no gun, none was needed. He pushed a knee into his guts. Then twisted his right wrist with an extended palm while simultaneously head butting him into the jaw, breaking it. As the fifth fell, he grabbed his neck and rotated it easily, almost effortlessly.

title: 10-15 Nov : 5 day off
post_content: Here is just that day I was waiting for. No mail, no queries, no enhancements, no pending work… so far. Just 7 days away from completing 1 full year in Infosys makes me as excited as adding one year- every year to my age.This is the right day for me to remember and pen down the beautiful year that just few by leaving behind some scented petals.Memories of year 1:Just a few days of rest after the college life for few and a big leap from a small company for others, the journey into the heaven scented land of Mysore began. There is no better place to start his career than Infosys, to add to it, Mysore Infy. I can still feel the excitement, enthusiasm and bliss everyone had on 15th of March 05. In the vast campus with some big buildings and motherly maintained greenery added to the excitement.Some carried the work experience with them and many were still kids, Infy took the responsibility to bring them all to the same level, 1 year later I feel they were quite successful. A mentor as old in Infy as we were took the reigns of driving the 180 people wagon through 120 days. He had a special charm, the ability to convince people with a ‘no’ added with a naughty smile – Sujith. He did more than what we expected to make the journey smooth.The days of the college were back: books, tests, exams, results, library, and night-outs. The josh for people to study picked up as compre-started nearing. Tests were minor hiccups which impacted more in the beginning but were restricted only to book-bugs later on.It would be a crime on not to mention on how the days were spent in the luxurious hostel. Rs.50/day for it was not even sufficient for the daily smile of the care-taker of the rooms.Waking up at 7, switching on the TV on full volume, barging into the bathroom to freshen up, calling up Akhi, Shreyas, karthik too meet for breakfast, fighting for which row to sit in the class, cribbing on the same old menu, planning for an outing, coming back into the room, switching on the AC in full power – having a feel of the Arctic’s, calling all the numbers in the telephone book, planning on which channel to watch, joining in again for dinner, lazy walk back to the hostel from the café, snehanshu’s love stories, chat with Arko, Kanta, Bajpai, Siju, Anirudh, Narahari late in the nights sometimes on the rooftop and striking the bed thinking about the new friends you made. Well did I ever mention studies? Oh ya… that to was sometimes cramped into the daily fun-itinerary. Smoking restriction in the rooms brought out some fun filled days between Kanta and Ashwarya. I still cannot forget some wonderful moments spent on the stair-case of the hostels along with some entertainment stunts from Arijith. Cannot even forget the enjoyable trouble Ramesh n Anand gave with their particular ‘requirements’. There are many I have missed out but be sure I haven’t forgotten any, not even the afghan dress of Priya or the string slippers of deepika for which I pulled their legs like crazy.Other than the resort err. Infy campus the time spent in Chamundi Hills, eating Mallige Idli’s, wiling away time in the go-carting tracks, the travel from the remote infy campus to the city, ride on bikes, going in big groups- how they race through my mind leaving the trace of smile on my face.4 months in Mysore, the trip back home was one of the most cherished moments. The games we enjoyed in train with colleagues trying to out beat each other, the best of dumb-charades from Deepika, sleepy Soumya & Shreyas, chirpy Priya n Chaitra, noisy Nidhi, silent but witty Akhi, the politically ‘wrong’ Kanta, the amazing technical discussions with Shaz n Karthik, the great drives in my car and of course ‘one’ most memorable turn, man I miss them a lot.Finally came the compre, the results brought shock n surprise to many, including me. I had no hopes to clear it. But the result was such that it found me wanting just 2 marks more to hit the ‘A’ mark.  But I was through, like many more… that’s what most of them wanted anyway.The value of the time spent in Mysore was mainly felt when we were all parting ways to give back on what was spent on us by Infy. Tears rolled with the feeling that we might not see the people again with whom we spent the best parts of our lives. Messenger and mails would keep us together… even this faded out as the year went by.Training was over; finally, I was happy to be back in Bangalore with parents and friends. EISA it was, the department I would report to. The excitement to work there was short lived. I was desperate to change and fortunately moved over to the Banking domain. A fresher like me was graciously absorbed into the team. Raghu and Shwetha took pains to impart the procedures followed here, and of course taught the ever so confusing Directory structure of Finacle and complex vi editor. Then the usual monotonous work started, enhancing the tools and supporting them became a usual routine. Good work comes regularly but is short lived. Excitement in life now is just a bigger pay cheque and fatter perks.It was a wonderful journey. Passed though one of the most wonderful stations with probably the best people.

post_content: For some reason I am in a great mood. I think it has to do with my diet. I feel better and thinner. Today I looked at myself in the mirror and thought that my face looked thinner. author: Kementeus Xtian
title: mi segundo post en la vida..
post_content: Veamos a ver si ahora si me pongo las pilas y por lo menos escribo algo en el transcurso del año...Tengo como dos años de tener este blog y solo publique un post en mi historia creo, es triste pero esas mañas de estar escribiendo para que la gente sepa que estoy haciendo como que no me agrada mucho, mejor creo que escribire contando un par de locuras que se me han ocurrido durante el 2005, entre esas un par de cositas para que la gente interesada en aprender un poquito cada dia sobre ese maravilloso mundo de investigar las entrañas de la compu y similares sean satisfechas.Creo que el ansia de escribir algo de nuestra vida o lo que decimos o pensamos es inherente en el ser humano, desde los mayas o egipcions al escribir en sus monolitos y papiros las cosas cotidianas o los acontecimientos que ocurren hasta el tiempo actual donde la manera mas común es el abrir un blog. O sea, cuantas veces no he descubierto algo que me ha llevado mi buen tiempo y no he escrito nada? es como negarle a otros el privilegio de aprender de los errores de otros; hasta he pensado que podría ser una forma de autodesahogo, ahora ya con tantos comentarios y noticias realmente estúpidas que suelo leer a diario en internet pues.Veamos cuanto me demora la fiebre bloggera, creo que ya estoy algo viejo para esto...

author: Kinch
title: Wake Up, Neo
post_content: Sorry bout that -- kicked it all off then left it to rust in the summer sun like a '74 Duster.But thus is summer, and this summer in particular...a season of distractions to be sure. Sadly the July 4th weekend is well endeth, and the grind resumes on the morrow. Between pending work projects and packing for my impending move to a new residence, I expect the rest of July to evaporate forthwith in a puff of smoke.Tonight, however, I await an atypical pounding from a Midwestern thunderstorm, which is surging towards us in Doppler shades of deep green and yellow, as if we are Isengard and the Ents are falling upon us with great vengence and furious anger.I hope to pick up on a redrafting of a short story this evening...a story I've allowed to lie far too dormant after a round of feedback from friends/family. We'll see how it goes.In the meantime, some recent viewings/observations:1) Farenheit 9/11: Saw the film in a relatively packed theater today -- a riveting experience of op-ed film. Having willingly and unwillingly absorbed a considerable amount of buzz about the film's assertions prior to seeing it, and being stolid in my voting choice this fall, I didn't expected to be swayed nor surprised...but I was swayed (in a "cementing what I already believe" way) and surprised (by the emotional impact of the soldiers and their families who appear in the film -- the ones who carry the true in burden in any war where lives are lost). It was a powerful, thought-provoking film, and an essential counterbalance to the overwhelming bullshit of the rightwing nuts in TV/radio broadcasting. Huzzah.2) Salem's Lot: Anybody catch the recent TNT cable miniseries? The novel (by Stephen King) is an annual read for me, as I am continually bewitched by its entropic tempo, its ominous sense of predetermined doom for its characters, and above all its merciless humor. Anyways, it's one of my favorite King books, and yet again it's been fucked up in adaptation to the small screen.The best you can say about the 1979 version, starring David Soul and directed by Tobe Hooper (auteur behind the original "Texas Chainsaw Massacre"), is that it at least had James Mason as Straker. and a certain schlocky character to it (although depicting Barlow as Max Schrek's grunting cousin was a tragedy).In this latest remake I most of all resented the excess liberties writer Peter Filardi took in his liberal rearrangement of the characters and their relationships (Susan being estranged from Ben Mears rang particularly false, as did the confrontation with Father Calahan in NY). It had a few bright moments (Rutger Hauer in the dump site, the kids on the school bus), but overall a wasted opportunity.To be clear, I'm not opposed to making necessary cuts and rearrangements to adapt a novel to the visual medium --- Peter Jackson's LOTR being one of many great examples of how to do this correctly. But too much tweaking screws up the momentum of the original narrative. Don't second guess the King. Anyways, I imagine this will be out on DVD sooner or later, but I wouldn't waste my time. Read the book instead.3) Open Water: My pick for the sleeper flick to see this fall. Looks like a cross between Blair Witch Project and Jaws. Wow. Trailers are playing before "Farenheit 9/11". Nothing like a little shark action to liven the post-summer blockbuster season.

author: John
title: Summer
post_content: So yeah summer is just going by faster than a speeding bullet.  Couple of days ago, I went out with Kristine to go see Harry Potter.  I have no idea why the hell I went to go see that.  I've never read the books nor I have seen the first two movies.  But it was all good because I was with my Kristine.  So the Monday-Thursday happened(Inside Joke your never gonna guess it).  But yeah I was just confused the whole movie.  But I had a great time with my baby.  Anyways so yeah also my Yiayia had a minor stroke.  It was a pretty scary thing.  Then on Saturday, I went to the V103 Car & Bike Show.  It was so tight.  There were so many nice cars. OMG!  Sad thing is, I had to work at the show and not have too much time to look at the cars in the show.  I sat there and handed out flyers for hours.  There were soooo many people.  Good lord.  Anyways I also went to my uncles to go swimming have a little family get together for another birthday celebration for my sister.  So today was Fathers Day.  I spent a lot of time with my dad.  We went out to eat.  Then we went out to my grandfathers grave.  It was a very sad moment.  I miss him very much.  Then we went to my aunts house to go swim and eat dinner.  It was a very nice day.  So yeah next week is just gonna be great.  The only good thing will be my girlfriend's birthday on Friday.  Cant wait for that.  But lets see....Monday....Orthodontist.....Tuesday......Court for those bastards who put a gun to my head.........Wednesday.......I get to get my Wisdom teeth taken out!.....And the rest of the week......Soreness!

author: ter
title: Fly By
post_content: Time to update my blogWell, finally, finally. Back to SG. It really feels great to be back. Nothing beats SG. hahah.. Now i kinda appreciate everything here in SG. The traffic, the air, the people, etc.My flight landed on Singapore on Friday evening, instead of night. Thanks to my boss. But i feel like i kinda wasted my weekends. I was simply too tired to do anything. Didn't sleep on Thursday night and almost whole of Friday. That's almost 30 hours. And came back home, slept for more than 14 hours. woot! =PMet the gang @ Zouk. Well, it was my first time @ Zouk =P, after it revamped that is. Somehow it looks the same to me. Maybe only the design is different compared to the previous one. Of course, it feels great to see the guys after 2 months. And Beng, yah lah, it was me who put the ice. Only the 2nd round. hahah =PHad a group picture:Similarly, i've wasted my Sunday afternoon. 'Cause i reached home @ almost 5am. Woke up at 5pm, then realised i was supposed to meet yiming, zhihui, jenson. Met them for dinner at Orchard. Unfortunately, i've got "fly-aeroplane" by ming. He's still in his depression period, after his 7-years relationship ended. I can understand his situation.But anyway, had a good dinner with zhihui & jenson. And went borders to chill around.The decorations in Orchard this year... is pretty lousy.Weekly Overview11/28/2005 - 12/04/2005Have you considered that what's going down on Monday may have nothing to do with you? Reflect on the size and style of another person's shoes. And then, on Tuesday and Wednesday, relax into the idea of your smallness in the world -- not as any comment on your influence, but just to enjoy a healthy and productive instance of modesty. Like most emotions, this will pass. Thursday and Friday you're feeling the polar opposite of modest: You are huge. You are Paul Bunyan. The world is a forest and you're going to chop it down. Saturday and Sunday see you acting equally ambitious.I'm happy to come back home.Or should i say, i sooOOOOOOooOOOO happy to be back! =DMore things to come in December.16 days left to the test dayterOut~

author: nowherefast
title: oldness
post_content: so i moved to charlotte, nc. i didn't think that things would be this hard when i first came here. i really wanted to move away but being away from everyone was a little hard for me to deal with. i've spent many nights sad that i won't hear the next word that my niece will say or the next funny thing that she will do. i miss not being able to go out and chill with my friends. i thought things would get better after i got my job.... but as many of you know she did it again. yes the whole reason that i have moved down here was for the one person that i have loved more passionately then anyone. the move was really for her parents to open up a restaurant. moving away from everyone for something i didn't really belive in was hard for me to deal with. before i moved away things were great between us. i had no doubts that things would last even though i knew that everyone else thought that i was stupid for doing it. love i guess does stupid things sometimes. the drive down was great. the weather was even better. things did get a little rough when i couldn't find a decent job. for about two months i was at home rather depressed that i wasn't going anywhere. she did do her best to help but i still felt lost. things just went a little haywire when she didn't want to spend the night with me after i didn't see her for a couple of days. during that time i started my job and the 3rd day that i was there my car was hit by a stupid guy and i just needed someone. i got mad about her not being there for me and things got out of hand. this is the second time that when i needed her the most she walked away with out any feeling what so ever. i know i know i haven't been with her to see if she has cried like i have or if she feels anything but right now i have to go by what i see. so there you have it the quick story.

author: Nixon Casablanca
title: Homespun Symposium XII
post_content: Call me ignorant, naive, Chester, whatever, but I had never heard of this term before yesterday, when Yahoo featured THIS STORY about a blogger being fired for bad-mouthing her employer on her blog.You need not scroll down too far to see a small rant about my own employer, and I know of several other blogs I read that frequently complain about where they work.While I try to keep my comments limited to things I wouldn't mind saying to my boss's face, or slip into the 'suggestion box' at work, some others have gotten a bit more therapeutic than I have in their posts.This brings up the whole "Free Speech" vs. "Free Enterprise" debate, that'll make any red-blooded American's cowboy hat spin. Quite honestly, I'm on the proverbial fence with this one. I'm an 'at will' employee where I work, which means if they suddenly decide that I'm too fat, too white, too Republican, too much of an OU fan, too ugly, or just really really want to hire someone else to fill my position, they can tell me goodbye at any second. Luckily, I'm in an industry that few people want to work in, and with high turnover, so any happy, loyal employee such as myself has pretty good job security. (Yes, I really do love my job!)But if I started posting lies and half-truths, or even whole truths that paint my employer in a bad light, would they be justified in firing me? And just who are they firing? "Nixon Casablanca" (not my real name.) Yes, that' s my real picture, but couldn't I just as easily post as someone else? Or use a fake picture? Or post as a pet armadillo? I don't blog on company time, mainly because we have no internet access at work. If we did, I probably would, but only because I mostly work graveyard during which time we watch the kids sleep (and make sure they don't wake up and try to escape, stab eachother, etc.) We do have a LOT of paperwork to keep us busy, but we still manage to have several hours of idle time a night, which is usually filled with reading or light television watching.So, I've reached no conclusion, but then again, neither did the news story. Where do YOU stand?

author: petitePiNkmoon
title: petitePiNkmoon
post_content: The more things change, the more they stay the same... I'm not sure who the first person was that said this. Probably Shakespeare. Or maybe Sting. But at the moment, it's the sentence that best describes my tragic flaw: my inability to change. I don't think I'm alone in this. The more I get to know other people, the more I realize it's kind of everyone's flaw. Staying exactly the same for as long as possible, standing perfectly still... It feels safer somehow. And if you are suffering, at least the pain is familiar. Because if you took that leap of faith, went outside the box, did something unexpected... Who knows what other pain might be out there waiting. Chances are it could be even worse. So you maintain the status quo. Choose the road already traveled. And it doesn't seem that bad, not as far as flaws go. You're not a drug addict. You're not killing anyone... Except maybe yourself a little. But, when we finally do change, I don't think it happens like an earthquake or an explosion, where all of a sudden we're like this different person. I think it's smaller than that. The kind of thing most people wouldn't even notice unless they looked really close. Which, thank God, they never do. But you notice it. Inside, to you that change feels like a world of difference. And you hope that it is. That this is the person you get to be forever... that you'll never have to change again. - - E.B.

author: Jon
title: The Twenty-fifth
post_content: Hey guys, what’s up? This is Jon and I’m here for another entry of YMU.I had a good weekend. My school was showing Ray and I saw it on Friday. Definitely Oscar worthy now that I’ve seen it for myself. I’ve been reading The Color Purple for my African American Lit class. It’s different. It’s told in prayers. I like it. I gotta see the movie after I’m done.Now about the topic. Today I went to church and I was feeling a little bad about a few things. Lately I’ve been feeling that I don’t have time to things I want to do. It’s always homework. I do my best not worry and trust God in everything, but it seems easier said than done most of the time. During worship I prayed to God to give me encouragement. Next thing I know one of the disciples had a verse that came to his heart and it spoke to me. 2 Corinthians 12:7-10. Paul was going through a rough time and the Lord said to him “My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.” Paul realized that even though he was feeling week he was going to rejoice in Christ’s strength and let him take over. That’s something that I need to do. Having apprehension and all this stuff won’t make your problems any better. You just have to bring them to Jesus and trust that everything is going to be brighter.I do have a bit of bad news. There was a shooting at a mall in my hometown, Kingston, NY. My mom told me about it today. It was one gunman and he injured a man in the leg.  Please pray for that man that everything turns out all right. He's in critical condition.I want to leave on a good note, so seeing as how Valentine’s Day is tomorrow, I have a special poem I wrote for the occasion. It’s called Real Love.My mind was boggled with woe and doubtMy body double over by a massive amountI started to teeter and began to quitDefeat was something I had to admitBut someone grabbed on and started to pullSoon I was up and saw you in fullYou comforted me giving assuranceThat you’ll be there for the next occurrenceI strolled down a path of darkness and forbidI tripped and fell and scurried and hidYour eyes filled with anger and mouth filled with scoldBut you wrapped me up close in your loving holdWhen you fixed my scrapes I didn’t understandTell me why you’re here I said with commandYou looked in my eyes and in a sweet voiceYou said I’m here because that is my choiceI love you and it hurt to see you in painThen I had a strange feeling that I yearned would remainA sense of joy exploded insideAnd my long journey had its demiseI had traveled to seek a real, true loveWhen all that was needed was to look aboveI’ll be back with more soon. Until then this is Jon saying, “God’s love is sufficient.”

author: The Patriot
title: Bathing Suits
post_content: Every year, when a major hurrican is about to hit the coast of the United States, the news media is there giving us wall to wall coverage. We have all seen the "brave" weatherman (or just the guy that drew the short straw) in a yellow rain suit standing out in the storm with his microphone in had trying to describe what it is like in 60+mph wind and rain.Before it hits, they cover the evacuation operations and show people boarding up windows preparing for the storm. They interview people who are leaving, asking them where they are going and if they are afraid their house will be damaged when they get back. But one thing I hear every time, one comment from a citizen that occours every time a hurrican hits. Even last year when four hit Florida in a row. I don't understand this comment. Maybe it is because I do not live there and live where things like this or other natural disasters do not occur.The comment that bothers me is when someone says that they had to drive to the next town to find a generator or that there was a rush at the hardware store to buy generators. What, they didn't buy one the last four times? Or did they buy one, but need a different one for this particular hurricane. What happened to the one they bought the last hurricane? I would think that if you lived where the treat of hurrican is always there, people would already have a generator or a plan of escape.I am not going to say these people are stupid, but come on. Every time, the news goes through the same old story, same lines, same consultants. And when they talk to people in the path of the hurricane, it is the same story every time. I had to search everywhere for a generator.Well, there it is. I am watching Fox News and there is the weather man standing in the rain trying to describe how hard the rain is falling and how hard the wind is. His rain suit is yellow. I don't know why it bothers me. Maybe because it seems just so stupid. It is a HURRICANE! Of course the wind is blowing. Of course it is raining. Of course the waves are pounding.Ok. That is enough of my rangingThis is One Man's Opinion

author: george
title: Memorial Day/Mom's birthday
post_content: We've spent the last 6 weeks nursing two injured Basenji's back to health. Basenji's are an African Hound dog. They are used for hunting small game. Our 4 year old 'senji's, Bob (25 lbs) and Lucy (23 lbs) decided they didn't like Jake, our 120 pound Lab-Rottie mix. They proceeded to open a can of whup ass on him. It didn't work. Jake cleaned their clocks. Lucy had a front leg broken and foot nearly chewed off. Bob had major muscle damage to his upper rear leg, his penis was bitten off and belly ripped open. Our Vet managed to repair them to near perfect condition. This was the first time Bob had attacked Jake. Lucy tried it two years ago and received injuries to her head, neck and chest. Basenji's are not known for having good sense. We did not buy these dogs. There's no dog in the world worth $600-$1000 each. All our dogs have been strays. Four years ago on Memorial Day weekend my wife opened the front door to get the newspaper and they were curled up on the porch bench. They ran in the house, jumped on the sofa and went to sleep. They had no collars, tags or microchip. We spent a month trying to find their owners without luck. Basenji's are really weird dogs. They are like a cat in a dog costume. They don't bark but make a noise like a human yawn sound. They will eat nearly anything that will fit down their throats. Bob's favorite treat is oranges. Lucy likes cucumbers with blue cheese dressing.

author: Jeff Robinson
title: Third Year Anniversary
post_content: Third Monk Records continues to develop artists and release product on an international scale.Cool.May 21, 2005 will see the Detroit release (national release to follow within 60 days) of the Penumbrae debut 11-song CD entitled "One Way Drive".  Careful work since September has made this disc what it is and the band sound brilliant.  A 5-piece quintet bridging the sonic gaps between Phish-Pink Floyd and Radiohead.  Basic tracks were cut at the Tempermill Studios in Ferndale, Michigan and ensuing overdubs were done with the Third Monk mobile unit at various locations around Metro Detroit.Since the disc was mastered by Gavin Lurssen at the Mastering Lab, songs have already been aired on WSDP-FM, WHFR-FM, WRAX-FM and the band have performed live on the nationally syndicated Mitch Albom show as well as in the studios of WHFR-FM at Henry Ford Community College.  Further non-comercial radio airplay and a fall tour to college campuses in the midwest are in the cards for the band.  Let's wish them the best!Thanks to everyone who participated in the iTunes/Pepsi promotion.  With the deadline for use of Pepsi product caps with free downloads passing on May 23, 2005, we are grateful to anyone who had the opportunity to download Third Monk Records artists for free.  Songs from Third Monk Records artists remain available at all paid download sites from iTunes to Aol.com to Audiolunchbox.com.After the analog tape scare we had back in December, it is a great, great thing that Quantegy tape has been bought by 2 past employees.  The analog tape domain is precious and without it, the record making process would be seriously hindered.  Even in the face of the Digital Audio Workstation, the essence of analog tape can still be an essential ingredient to produce amazing  recordings of great songs.  Better still to think that Emtec (BASF) is back in the fray and ATR Services in Pennsylvania will be making their own analog tape.The music industry should continue to regain it's strength in the next 5 to 10 years while it recovers from the attack of the evil 3-headed hydra- namely Corporate Radio, illegal MP3 downloading and the advent of the Digital Audio Workstation.  With great trepidation, we should all be concerned and closely monitor the Elliot Spitzer Payola investigation in New York State and encourage legislation to be passed in Washington, D.C. to eliminate the ridiculous concept of songs as 'paid' advertisements.  As for the rest, everyman is empowered with their Digitial Audio Workstations and the industry finally has a grasp on how to make money selling mp3s.Let's hope for the best!

post_content: First posts are always awkward.  Especially when you don't know what direction your site/blog/whatever is going to take.  The first post dictates the future content, theme, audience, and whatever random item that people will wind up reading when they come to the page or read the column.  And right now, I have no idea where this thing is going to be taken.  I just know that this is going to be a total gateway into each and every chaotic, random, bittersweet moment that occurs.  Add a dash of blatant honesty, strong opinions and whatever wit I can force out.  Good lord, I hope I don't bore the masses (or lack thereof) to death.

author: efatima
title: Sympathy
post_content: Dreams show us the interior landscape of the mind, the contours of our fears and wishes.  Dreams can be warnings or indications, beckoning us to a new level of learning or a new aspect of life that we must learn to face.The journey towards greater authenticity and innter connectedness is not an external adventure only.  Of course, we must move out into the world, utilizing our gifts and making real our dreams.  At the same time, we need to face our inner deamons - whether they be fears of failure and humiliation, repressed rage, narcissism, or even an excessive mistrust of people.  Dreams, especially recurring drams, may invite us into this inferno, reminding us of the inner work before us.efatima's journal

author: Cory
title: Cory (mtngant)
post_content: What a great bowl season we had this year. Great games and an awesome National Championship game.The Ducks performance was the only downer. We should have won. We played poorly and sadly I have to point to the coaching staff and their decisions.As for the rest of the top games, wow, Ohio State really impressed me in the Fiesta Bowl against Notre Dame, the Buckeyes are impressive. The Sugar Bowl, it looked like after the end of the first half that they would both score 60 points, amazing offenses. It was a fun first half of football. Of course they slowed down in the second half and it was a battle to the end.All of the BCS bowls were battles, the Orange Bowl, wow! Three overtimes! The missed field goals, the intensity was great, I was sure glad Kevin Kelly came through with his third chance to win the game. I am not sure he would have lived to old age if he would have missed another. Paterno and Bowden are the two winningest coaches in D-I football battling it out for over 4 hours (79 years old and 76 years old respectively). It was cool to watch.Then there came the Rose Bowl for the National Championship. I was saying before the game, this is the most significant football game of the century. Texas and USC, all the stories to be told, wow. Texas ranked number two all season, had an amazing year, routing most all of the teams they came up against. After the game commentators were asking if Vince Young (runner-up Heisman candidate) might be the best quarterback ever! He is amazing, he ran for 200 yards and He threw for 267 yards, in the Rose Bowl for the National Championship! This Young’s second year in a row winning the Rose Bowl, his combined yardage and amazing …. 839 yards in two Rose Bowls."That," USC coach Pete Carroll said, "is an extraordinary football player.""Vince is truly one of the great competitors to ever play college football," coach Mack Brown said Wednesday night. "He has got a tremendous amount of confidence. He just exudes that confidence."And the USC Trojans … Matt Leinart comes back passing up tens of millions of dollars this year to go for his 3rd National Championship in a row. He was the Heisman winner in 2004, the top player in the whole nation. This year Reggie Bush, running back for USC, wins the Heisman and he deserved it he is like no other, he runs by defensive players like they are 7th grade girls. Two Heisman winners on one team playing for their 3rd National Championship, guarding a 34 game winning streak, they had not lost since 2003!Now the game, wow, they battle to the final seconds. There was no way to know the final outcome until the buzzer rang. Intense. Wow. That was fun.

author: T
title: No suicide yet...
post_content: Well things are toddling along. I went on BBC London last night to discuss the next day's papers witha very funny woman called Stella Duffy and the DJ, both of whom are ludicrously quick and hilariously funny. I was a bit stuffy alongside and my lack of encyclopaedic knowledge about showbiz didn't help. But whatever, the highlight of the evening was the cab ride home. I was driven by a Bulgarian guy who had made and lost fortunes in Bulgaria and told me a few explicit truths - summed up as 'don't waste your youth worrying'. I've often been under the impression that life is sending me clues, very much in the way omens are sugested by Paolo Coelho in the Alchemist. Except I don't believe in a higher power - at all - and so it makes it easy for me to ignore these impressions I get. But the truths are getting clearer and louder - I can't keep ignoring the evidence that I am wasting my life. I am pissed off - I am pissed off with my flatmate, who is also pissed off with life, I am pissed off with my job, where the confidence has drained out of me to an unrealised extent. I am pissed off with my inability to get out of bed to get to work on time, my inability to organise my life at all, my inability to get and hold down a relationship. I have all that anyone could want - I look reasonably nice, I'm quite intelligent, quite witty. I'm not the best at anything, but I have talents. Yet I find it so difficult to do or say anything at all. My only role among my friends is as a kind of eccentric. Maybe I have CJD. I'm still wearing my Dad's shirts. I never iron them. Myt trousers don't fit. Blah fucking blah - I bore even myself. Basically my life is barely tolerable. But I need to try to make money somehow. I like learning Arabic. I like salsa but it's hard to keep from thinking it's an exam rather than a pleasure. I DON'T KNOW WHAT TO DO. And I certainly don't know why I am putting all this up on a website next to a photo of me (well; noone is reading so it barely amtters). How postmodern, showing all the workings, except I don't feel like anything is working at all. and I feel the longer it doesn't the further away any prospect of realising any potential recedes. I am so used to failure now, personally and professionally, that I am slipping into a role of a bitter, disatisfied person whose creative synapses have withered through lack of use. I retain a certain arrogance, thinking wrongly that I could have been a prince, but under that increasingly brittle shell I am hollow. One day I will just collapse and the pieces will simply blow away.

author: Dana
title: Rob's brother is a dick and the tree party
post_content: I was in Rob's bedroom, and Melissa was there. We both were taking a final exam for some teacher. It was a pretty hard test, and at one point the teacher came in the room to check on us. She left, and told us we had only 20 minutes left. She shut the door behind her, and I started freaking out because I didn't think I could finish it. Melissa and I started talking, and Melissa told me one of the answers. She didn't really *say* it, she was singing it, over and over again. As she was doing this both our parents walked into the room. Melissa didn't seem to notice, and she kept singing the answer. I tried to shut her up, but our parents saw that she was giving me an answer. The teacher walked in a few seconds later, oblivious that Melissa gave me and answer. However, my dad told her! The teacher became VERY angry, and grabbed our tests from us and told us that we failed the class for cheating. I started crying and begging her to reconsider, saying that we were not cheating. I really did not believe that we had cheated at all. I was so afraid I would not graduate on time because I would have to retake the class.
