author: infinity
title: the answer
post_content: The Answer:WHO ARE WE ?WHAT IS THE ULTIMATE GOAL OF THE HUMAN EXPERIENCE?What is time?What is the purpose of time? does it begin or end? Does it move? Is it static? Is today tomorrow´s yesterday? What is humanity´s role or purpose in this static continuum?Civilizations appear and disappear. We appear and disappear and between one event and the other, time gives us its precious gift, the gift of existence. Life, death , growth, decay, happiness, joy, decease, sadness, healing, wealth, our own survival depends on time. Everything depends on it. Everything changes between one event and another. With the passage of time everything changes, even static things age in constant flux and transformation. We are not the same creatures we started out being nor are we the same persons we will become. We transform. One being completely different in body and mind. Evolved from simple to complex through growth. We are an expression of time, change and evolution.Is evolution, growth, transformation or time creations of a higher power or a mindless universe ?These writings do not attempt to deal with those questions, they only attempt to establish certain links and correlations between them: Evolution takes time. Time expresses itself through evolution. Evolution is a transformation.Time is all.Evolution and transformation come about as an expression. The Human expression exists through inter-dependent phenomena. An expression with an ultimate goal: Full development. In social evolution the goal is to express a human being fully self-contained, physically and intellectually with no further need of corrective after thought devices like laws or archaic arithmetical monetary systems to deal with each other. What for? if each human is complete and total, developed through: Knowledge. Extensive education, as much as each person desires. A social minimum> 20 years? 25? 30?A society that exists in time like anything else; evolves. It makes its developmental pattern from simple to complex automatically through growth and change . The goal of any society is to make things better through some means or other. If its members are not allowed to fully develop, intellectual corollary systems will be developeded to fill in the vacuum. Social institutions, correctional specially, will obligatorally be developed through the evolutive mechanism. Laws will have to be created and enforced depending on what was not fully acomplished in the preceding evolutive step. If in the human relations area; laws, courts, police forces will fill in the vacuum. If in the spiritual area, religions will fill in the vacuum.To survive on this planet, humanity has experienced the hard way to interact and exchange within itself and with every specie on it, one way or another. The earliest was the barter system; with the animal kingdom: I´ll keep you, I´ll feed you, I´ll take care of you, in exchange -- Ill take your hide or your meat. With the plant and mineral kingdom it has been basically the same exchange plus, we have learned not to pollute or we will not be able to breath.In bartering, if there are human beings not fully develloped, who do not understand the laws of equilibrium, ( equal exchange ), in other words think that they can or should get something for nothing, then social evolution will take over and fill the void: it will develop systems that will force them if not to undertand at least to make them live in relative harmony with the imposed laws, regulations of the corrollary corrective systems.  Among the developed systems: the monetary system.If knowledge is not diseminated equally among the members of a society and some remain somewhat ignorant or completly ignorant of their roles in their group or society, geographical area, planet, space in time, history or universe and if barriers like language or distance seem insourmoutable like in societies early development, the monetary corrective system will become an evolutionary necessity.Money: An artificial mathematical exact systems of transaction, to help with the vacuum that ignorance produces. If the individual does not know how to deal with the rest of the group, rules will be imposed on him.The monetary system depends on its own inherent rules and regulations that must be adhered to for it to work, for as in any mindles system it works on his own terms.If a corrective system like the monetary one is used, societys highest potential has not been reached.Money performs at its best in concret terms, with tangibles. It does not understand or deal with feelings, morals or ethics. Usualy, morals suffer like in the following example: we are always chasing after the better deal. The more for less deal. In shopping, we want more for less, to the point that we are willing to turn a blind eye if a product has to be manufactured in a less developed country where labor is cheaper even if the working conditions are sub-human.Another aspect of money or mathematical transaction that is almost imposible to understand is the disconnect.The disconnect relates to when something has or appears to have no connection with another, example: Addiction to drugs. Nine out of ten drug addicts at the time they purchase them do not relate to the chain of events unleashed at that moment, specially when many of the events will happen to other peoples in other lands far away from them in time and space.The "more for less" aspect is especially difficult to assimilate specially when dealing with intangibles like the ones mentioned above, it engenders a host of problems and is based soley on mechanical transaction, a transaction that is sometimes not easily understood by a not sufficiently developed or evolutionized or knowledgeable person. In that sense, if we continue to have under educated people we will have the same problem. The numbers game can be manipulated in other ways by those who know.More work from employee: for less wages.More price: for less quality.And on , and on , endlessly.The more for less theory is applied throughout the system, inflation is a vital part of it and we are constantly trying to catch up with it. Quality of life is forced to be cheepened in every respect. It is the only way the system can work.New language emerges such as: Corporate Economic Restructuring. Whereby the company must produce more with less workers and cheaper materials and thousands of jobs and lives are erased and destroyed.UTOPIA (Does it exist?)There is no such thing as social human utopia.It is the ultimate goal of evolution ( any evolution ) to attain perfection. Eventually language will include words like cheat, steal, rob, even the word truth only in a historical context "when man was underdeveloped and there existed social corollary suport systems to fill in .Basic law of time: Relativity.To the cave man democracy is utopian. To us they are undeveloped.Obviously the best society is one based on truth and trust alone with no need for correcting systems like money because clearly; if you are fully and totally developed, you will always do what is ethically and truthfully correct and to the end : Truth is the great equalizer.. A trust that comes about becaues you know that whatever anybody says or does (exept for mistakes or lack of knowledge which will be aknowleged and quickly corrected) must be true and ethical because there are no hidden purposes, pressures or agendas.Only mankind strives to understand concepts of time and evolution in its relentless persuit for perfection. The only question is : How much time will it take us to fully accept that fact and how long are we to make the intervening steps of understanding and acceptance:days,years,millenia?It is hard for us to imagine or accept from our point of view, a more different world but it is only a question of relativity.If and only if EVERY AND EACH human being on this planet is fully develloped socially through knowledge and education so that we have no need for corrolary systems like:* MoneyReligionLawLaw Enforcement*These 4 concepts will only exist in history books.The only motivation needed for a fully developed person to act is the eagerness to participate in an environment that is truthful, fair, exiting and willing to share all its physical, spiritual and intellectual riches. Social and cultural evolutions are intrinsically linked to their environment. All three are depndent on each other and develop accordingly, to a certain extent they react automatically.If corrective systems are allowed to exist for too long, they become the norm and they grow and develop themselves and with beings as sophisticated, sensitive and social as human beings, they bring around the problem of invisible social barriers and intellectual barriers like political division and money division.If a well developed colony of ants or bees who had reached the peak of their development were to be put in the same predicament, they would soon find themselves in our same situation> at odds with each other.As long as we hold on to our knowledge vacuums where some members of our societies remain undeveloped, socialy we will not be free.We will remain slaves to our inability of seeing beyond the next curve.The only way out is to lift up from ignorance every single child alive, everywhere in this planet.The answer is : Knowledge through education. So we do not have to deal with the corrective systems.No money.No religion. ( Spirituality, Yes)No Laws.No need for any of them. If every single one of us is illuminated inside by knowledge.

post_content: Begin burst transmission..."Geez...What luck. The janitor finally comes in, scrubs all the blood out of my basin from when that asshole sprayed his bloody urine all over me, and he gives me a brand spanking, never-been-pissed-on, perfectly circular vanilla-scented urinal cake. And guess what. No more than 22 hours later, I'm baptised in diseased blood all over again...except this guy looked a little worse. He comes stumbling in, muttering something about "those God-Damned Monkees", and starts running in circles, with blood pouring out of every visible orfice. This guy was cuckoo...Or a cokehead. However, if I understood him correctly, his spinal column had dislodged itself and was slowly inching out of his ass. That can't be comfortable...God I almost feel sorry for him again....Almost. Oh well things could be worse, I guess. See that toilet in Desparado? Yeah, things could be worse...But why couldn't I have been accidentally installed in the Ladies' room? Is that too much to ask? I'm growing tired of gazing at old, uncircumsised men and their unproportionate, not-very-circular testicles. I want women...Oh well. I still smell the vanilla. That's got to count for something." -from The Book of Shapes--end transmission...

author: paulinha
title: Meu mundo
post_content: É seguro dizer que eu nunca deixei de pensar em você. A verdade é que nunca houve um dia, desde que eu te conheci, em que isso não ocorresse.&nbsp;Não seria diferente depois que você tivesse partido.&nbsp;Quando algo assim acontece, por muito tempo as lembranças nos assombram. E mesmo as melhores, as mais felizes são extremamente dolorosas.&nbsp;Exatamente por isso, coloquei você em um cantinho escuro da minha mente.&nbsp;Credito tal atitude ao meu instinto de sobrevivência.&nbsp;Foi um período extremamente confuso.&nbsp;O que, no fundo, eu não gostaria de admitir era que você havia se tornado uma parte da minha história. E o que somos nós, senão o produto de nossa história? Logo, você também virou um coeficiente da minha equação e ao apagar você, eu estava simplesmente apagando parte de mim. E como eu poderia desejar ser inteira?Fui eu quem te disse que o amor é capaz de superar tudo, até mesmo a morte. Pro seu mundo exato, tanta subjetividade era extremamente inquietante. E você preferia dizer que eu era ingênua, uma romântica e dava muita importância ao que dizia meu coração, quando, à seu modo, você era tão mais romântico que eu.Hoje, com mais convicção que antes, volto a repetir: o amor, meu querido, vence tudo. Sobrevive até às corrosões do tempo. Intacto. Move, inclusive, montanhas de orgulho, em não querer dar a você a sua devida importância por simples medo de sofrer.Se eu pudesse te encontrar agora, eu diria simplesmente que eu o amo, com a mesma certeza que sempre tivemos que seria pra sempre.Diria então pra você ir sem medo, que poderia seguir o caminho que Deus desenhou pra você, ainda que isso significasse nunca mais nos ver. Porque, da mesma forma que estar perto não é o mesmo quer estar junto. Estar longe, não é o mesmo que estar separado.E se eu pudesse, enfim, redizer o que eu te disse na última vez em que te vi, desejaria simplesmente que você seja, sempre, imensamente feliz e que mesmo quando tudo parecer impossível, nada tema, pois o amor é capaz de tudo, de nos resgatar dos mais profundos abismos, de renovar nossas forças quando tudo parece acabado, de nos elevar aos céus.&nbsp;"O Amor é paciente, é benigno; o Amor não é invejoso, não trata com leviandade, não se ensoberbece, não se porta com indecência, não busca os seus interesses, não se irrita, não suspeita mal, não folga com a injustiça, mas folga com a verdade. Tudo tolera, tudo crê, tudo espera e tudo suporta. O Amor nunca falha."Por isso, de todas as atribulações, de quaisquer mundos, asseguro-te: você há sempre de encontrar abrigo na certeza de que não há nada mais fortificante, nem renovador do que a pureza do amor verdadeiro e a paz que ele nos traz.Que assim seja.

author: Jungian
title: The Internet: What Lies Ahead?
post_content: In the early days of the internet, social networking, where real exchange, sharing and communication between people took place was limited to newsgroups and email.Now the internet has taken on a whole new evolution. I like to call it “people power”. What used to be called consumers have become the Internet producers. It stared with message boards, went on to P2P, online gaming, photo sharing and finally nuevo journalism or blogging. It gives social networking a whole new direction. The act of sharing be it their day, thoughts, opinions or photos, these new producers are dictating where the Internet begins and ends. The new producers of content will inevitably take over from mainstream media.In the process of sharing is where a gateway to the future of the internet was revealed. When each person began to reveal their truths and realized that there are more similarities between people than there are differences. This awareness has created a power stream and thus a shift in the collective consciousness. A new form of thought leadership is bound to emerge from this. But unlike the lone figure standing on a pedestal speaking for his people, this it will be the collective voice of all humanity. And the microphone thru which they speak will be the INTERNET.That can never be a bad thing. Because for once decisions will be made collectively. In the process of doing so, the connection the internet provides will show that ultimately we want the same things.These communities are already talking and the power brokers are listening. With this change, it begs the question, what will the Internet become?The internet will become the channel and the reference point for every new invention. It will become an ecosystem that states what we want, what we need, and how we need it. The way businesses deal with this will be the challenge. Because previously, an invention was made and marketed and only after getting feedback was it improved upon (Microsoft is a good example) and then it went on to be called innovation. This time around, the winning invention is the one that was commissioned by the producers of the internet. Not literary commissioned, but as natural progression that comes when millions of people around the globe share their views, thoughts and opinions about what stays and what goes.It will not only shape the economics and politics of the world but lift the collective consciousness of humanity to level never before experienced. With blogging and other forms social networking, there is now a source where almost every human mind is plugged into. This source is an invaluable tool that will make a difference whether we like it or not.

author: Christiaan
title: GOOD ENOUGH
post_content: São Francisco - Americana processa Apple e pede US$ 225 mil em indenização pela explosão do tocador dentro da calça do filho de 15 anos. Uma mulher de Ohio, Estados Unidos, entrou com um processo contra a Apple na semana passada, alegando que o iPod Touch de seu filho explodiu, causando queimaduras. Por conta disso, ela pede 225 mil dólares de indenização pelos danos. Na ação, ela explica que o iPod Touch de 16 GB de seu filho de 15 anos estava no bolso da calça, durante uma aula. De repente, o garoto teria ouvido “o barulho de um estouro e imediatamente sentiu uma sensação de queimadura em sua perna”. Foi então, segundo o documento, que ele percebeu que “o equipamento estava em chamas”.

author: Manish
title: Roses
post_content: From WSJ Posting  - 11/18The total package. Almonds, honey, orange blossoms and earth. Luscious, with oranges, almonds and stewed peaches, but not at all heavy. Very smooth, with a lemon-meringue finish.Golden and green-tinged. A nose of nectar -- pears, apples, orange blossoms and peaches -- and roasted mixed nuts: walnuts, almonds, pistachios. Mouth-coating, with ripe apricots, great acids and egg-white fluffiness on the long, clean finish. Surprisingly light on its feet.[nowides] OUR FAVORITES [Tastings]In a tasting of Sauternes from the excellent 2001 vintage, these were our favorites.Sigh. Wait, where were we? Oh, here: Every year around this time, we're asked something like this: "I'd like to get a bottle of wine for a friend who's really into wine, but he already buys good stuff by the case, so what could I possibly give him?" This year, here's the answer: a bottle of Sauternes from the well-regarded 2001 vintage, which is just arriving in stores now. This is a gift that will show research and good taste, and it's truly one that will keep on giving for many years, but we'll get back to that.There is no sweeter gift than Sauternes, and we mean that literally. Sauternes, from the Bordeaux region of France, is the world's greatest sweet wine. (The name, sometimes spelled Sauterne, was appropriated by some American wineries for sweet, simple wines, but they're unrelated.) It is made from grapes -- Semillon and Sauvignon Blanc, sometimes along with Muscadelle -- that have been allowed to remain on the vine in misty conditions until they are attacked by botrytis cinerea, the famous "noble rot" that shrivels the grapes and concentrates the juice into a rare and remarkable nectar.Leaving the grapes on the vine until they are attacked by mold is obviously risky -- in fact, some Sauternes producers don't make any wine at all in troubled years. And harvesting those grapes and making this wine is labor-intensive and expensive. So these wines should cost a fortune, but, on the whole, they don't, we're happy to say, because sweet wines generally aren't in vogue.Genuinely ExcitingBut here's the thing: True wine lovers know the real value of Sauternes, and that's why this is such a great present. While many of the world's sweet wines are flabby sugar bombs, Sauternes is not. Think about the ripest, freshest, juiciest piece of fruit you've ever tasted. Sure, it was sweet, but the primary taste was fruit, not sugar, and the sweet tastes were probably balanced with some tartness and good acidity. That's the wonder of Sauternes. Its abundant acids, great earthiness and ripe fruit taste like juicy, fresh-from-the-tree-or-vine fruit, not like sugar. In a good Sauternes, the smell itself is both sweet and nicely acidic, making it mouth-watering even before it's sipped. At their best, these wines are genuinely exciting.Did we say earthiness? Heaven knows this is hard to explain, but in the very best Sauternes -- and especially the famous Chateau d'Yquem, the greatest Sauternes -- we sometimes feel as though we're drinking nectar that's been filtered through rich earth. It's that elemental -- and unique.The 2001 Yquem, which has been widely praised, hasn't yet been released. (It might be available for Christmas, at $400 a bottle or more.) But many other Sauternes from 2001 have hit the shelves, so we figured we'd pick up enough for a large tasting to see how they are. We set no price limit, so we ultimately spent up to $129.95, though most of the wines were less than $50. We bought wines labeled Sauternes and labeled Barsac, which is one of the villages of Sauternes and is allowed to use its own name. The wines of Barsac are generally considered somewhat lighter and perhaps a little more elegant than many wines labeled simply Sauternes.We are sometimes told that fine French wines aren't available in California -- can you imagine? -- so we made a point of buying most of the wines for this tasting there. We tasted the wines blind in flights over several nights, and we're here to tell you: These are delicious, memorable wines. Wine after wine offered a luscious nose of orange blossoms and brioche, a rich taste of fruit, earth and nuts, and a lingering finish of sweet, ripe fruit that sometimes left us at a loss for words. Or perhaps we just didn't want to speak and risk losing the state of mind that the taste had induced.Golden TastesDuring the tasting, John asked Dottie how we could describe Sauternes that might convince a sweet-resistant wine drinker to give it a try. Dottie thought for a moment and replied: "It's like the sun. There's a gleaming richness to it. It tastes golden. It's smooth, with a sweetness that bursts in your mouth and then surprises you with such a clean, bracing finish." As we said, sigh.We ultimately couldn't pick just one wine for our best of tasting. Two wines, both of which we rated Delicious, qualified for the top spot: Chateau de Malle, the wine we described above as "the total package," and the other one above, Chateau Nairac from Barsac, which had the fluffy finish, something you will just have to experience to fully understand.But this is important: These wines won't be at their best for many years. In fact, our advice for new parents who want to lay down wine for their child is always Sauternes because it ages so well for so long. Not only that -- and, for your present, this is particularly important -- but the wine gets more and more beautiful to look at as it ages. Even in youth, Sauternes is beautiful in its clear bottle -- golden, sometimes with green highlights. With each year, the wine gets even more stunning, with its gold becoming dark and richer-looking. Long before the bottle is open, it has already given such joy. So this holiday season, give your friend a bottle of 2001 Sauternes, but be sure to write something like this on the label: "Happy holidays 2005. May your life, like this wine, get better every year."

author: Cheryl
title: Ireland is calling!
post_content: In yesterday's Omaha World Herald there was an article that regarding how the news people take one story and repeat it over and over again. I couldn't agree with them more. Anymore it seems as if the same story runs day after day after day. How many times or how long do we really want to hear about Charles and Camilla's wedding, what she wore, that the Queen shunned her sons wedding, etc...... Do we really have that little in life to focus on that we have to keep reliving the same story day after day?  I think that the journalists could be a bit more creative in their stories.  It ends up being like a never ending novel!

author: Unknown
title: Snow baby
post_content: Hi Everyone,Greg and I headed to Palo Alto on Sunday to watch the 2008 Amgen Tour, which is a bike race throughout California.  The race started about 2 blocks from my work, so we thought it would be cool to see the streets shut down and the spectators all around.  The weather was great and we had free parking at my office, so why not check it out??My boss Brendan is really into biking, so he took these photos.  He was in a VIP tent (cuz he's that cool), so we didn't get to talk to him... but you'll see that Greg and I did say hello.I don't know who any of the riders are, but it was nice to stroll the streets of PA and Stanford University.

author: Zodiachus
title: When you are in distress, do something different...
post_content: I am still crying damn it, and it's an hour since you left. It's crazy, I haven't cried this much since... I never had I think.But it's not the kinda tearing apart self-pity crying, and it's not the crying that comes with a big black hole like when you have lost someone. It's the kind of crying that's like a big exclamation mark after the wonderful summer we've had together.I missed you when we were apart for two hours, and the weekend you were in Örebro was relatively easy to cope with because there came a monday after that weekend. This is bigger and I don't know what to do with myself.I've rolled up my sleeves, and the orange is waiting for me. I've also made a thermos of the tea that you bought in the beginning of the summer (chocolate and... whiskey?)When the train left I couldn't contain myself anymore. I had to go sit down, because standing up wasn't a good idea at that point.Later when I was waiting for the bus, I saw the sunrise, and god was it ever beautiful. It was like a big shining smile rising over the horizon. At that moment it felt like someone reassuring me, like it was communicating that all will be fine. It feels a little presumptuous to assume that we would have a sunrise dedicated to us, and nevertheless I feel that that was exactly what it was.Dangit! I'm still crying and it's making it damn hard to see what I type!Ooooooooh GOD I am looking forward to seeing you next time.I wish you well on your Dublin adventures, love. Remember that I believe in you. You're the best. Forever and ever. Amen.

author: Kathryn
title: Follow-Up to Rolling Hills
post_content: It seems that everywhere in today's world we are faced with situations that have to be dealt with morally and ethically.  Simple positions, without  responsibility still require moral decisions.  Even As a bartender w are faced with these types of decisions.  We are told that we can not accept gifts or extensive tips from our customers, yet everyday I see my fellow cast members leaving with flowers and stuffed animals.  That certainly isn't a personal jet used for a lavish vacation, but are we looking at the future person who will abuse power given it?  And how do we positively influence these people?  Is their even hope?  They know what is right and what is wrong, yet they continue to work for their own self interest.  People in society constantly amaze me.  We give power to CEO's and they continue to use their influence and power on board members and others to get what they want.  How can we fix this?  We know what is right and wrong.  We have outlines and definitions of the morals in health care and the conflicts of interest.  We need to avoid hiring people who may put their own interest before that of the company.  But how do we identify these people?  Anyone can get through an interview with all the right answers given the proper research. I guess all we can do is limit power until we gain trust and positively influence others in our work place.

author: Ray Seyfarth
title: My Katrina Garden
post_content: Katrina produces something goodAfter Hurricane Katrina, I had no house damage though most houses on my street had plenty.  I did have a magnolia tree in the backyard which had split near the ground during the storm and half of it was leaning for an hour or so.  Then the wind shifted and the tree righted itself.  It looked OK, but I thought it was probably not really healthy.I also had a pine tree which had been leaning since I moved in in 1990 toward a neighbor's house.  Her house had been damaged by her own pine trees during Katrina and she had all the trees removed.  I decided that I should remove the pine tree and the magnolia.  This left me with more sunshine than ever and some nice piles of wood chips.I thought the wood chips might be good for compost and the extra sunshine might be nice for growing some vegetables.   Now I know that wood chips take a long time to decompose.  Anyway I made a couple of compost bins out of a roll of rabbit cage wire and started composting wood chips mixed with dirt.  I planted some bell peppers, jalepenos, okra, squash and tomatoes.  They ended up being in poor soil and the wood chips were pitiful compost, so they were weak plants.  I misjudged the amount of sunlight in that spot.  I got no squash at all.  I probably got 2 or 3 okra pods, a dozen small bell peppers, a couple dozen small tomatoes and maybe 4 dozen small jalepeno peppers.  My neighbor gave me some cucumber plants and they produced perhaps a dozen cucumbers.My neighbor enjoyed watching me work and helped me out a bit.  He's 90 years old and still gardening.  He kept giving me veggies all summer.   I received more veggies than I grew, but I was happy to have started a relationship with my neighbor and enjoyed his produce.  We had a lot of tomato and cucumber sandwiches.  I started enjoying adding jalepeno to the sandwiches.  The Katrina garden was a little pitiful but I did have some nice food to eat and something positive to do.Better CompostThe first section of my garden had been in the area where my older son played basketball.  There was hard packed sandy soil.  Adding wood chips and planting in partial shade was altogether pretty silly.  I started cutting grass and composting grass clippings with some dirt.  After I had some better compost, I started digging a new area for planting.  I chose a little better. The new spot had grass growing and was in the sun.  The dirt looked much better and the compost was better.I planted yellow squash, cucumbers and okra in the second little plot.  I ended up with very large leaves on the squash plants and even had modest success with enough food to make it interesting.Fruit TreesThe wood chips made poor compost for veggies, but I thought that perhaps they would work with trees.&nbsp; I think they work best with "wild" type trees and vines.&nbsp; So far it seems that wood chips are great for muscadines.Ph MeterI have tried 2 different fairly cheap pH meters in my yard with total failure.&nbsp; I think that I will be forced to guess and over time learn what works in my area.&nbsp; I am fairly convinced that I have acidic soil, so I try to add lime depending on the plant's needs.&nbsp;

I have write an 'In-class Essay' tomorrow for English... It's dead stupid. 76 minutes to write something intellectual about Othello? I'd have better odds against a fool with a machete. Speaking of fools. I know lots of them. For instance; there was a car accident today at school. This kid who lives up my road (I think he hates my guts...) he probably screeched out of the car park, like most of the drivers try to do and got barrelling down the road off to some unknown restaurant in order to purchase some desired greasy, fatty food for lunch. And then, come storming back to school, in the company of foolish friends and finish up the rest of the day absorbing knowledge like a sponge. Not. It was funnu though because I was walking home for lunch (I like two seconds away) and I heard a tremendous clatter and instantly thought "Hah, it would be funny if someone went into the ditch." Only to hear ten minutes later from my thick as two short plants brother that someone had. Upon my return to school, he was sat on the bonnet of his faded red Jeep Cherokee with a solumn look upon his sunglassed obscured face. Indeed the noon-hour today happened with great incident.

author: K.G.
title: Happy 2005!
post_content: Tis the day to celebrate the Presidents...and I am cleaning my house.  I guess that in itself is a tribute to the life in the US. I never have enuf time to keep my house and room cuz I am friggin busy keeping busy. ay yay yay.  Theres a couple things I have observed that have been on my mind.BRIDGE! I love Bridge and its goals.  This program at Davis is meant to inspire Filipino students, if not all students, to pursue higher education.  I went to their 10th annual showcase this Saturday cuz my sister said they were inviting past board members.  I haven't been out to anything Bridge in so long so I thought hey, why not.  My sister and Stephen came too...yay one of my best guy friends and former board member.  WE felt old, as expected.  There were too many singing groups, also as expected.  But they were pretty good!  The one thing I was irritated with the whole night was the MC.  The guy MC kept talking about his after party and drinking/getting drunk at the after party, and being "moist and wet" from watching the performers.  1) There were parents there.  2) PYC youth were invited (all of high school age)  3) There was even a young performer there age 12 that was watching the show too.  What the hell kind of message are they sending to these kids? It makes it look like Bridge is trying to encourage kids to come to college cus its fun and you get to drink.  What is this? It's one thing for the performers to talk about that stuff, but the MC-- that reflects poorly on Bridge....upsetting.Whew...next more pressing thing.  I have a performance this Sunday.  It's a hula performance and it's making me alil bit nerviosa!  This Sunday, Feb 27  at 12pm at the San Ramon Multicultural Festival.  It should be fun and it's free for all watchers hehe.  So cmon out!  I rarely have nething that I want people to come out n watch...AND it's free woohoo!.  I'm nervous, I just hope I don't get too nervous during the show.  So practice practice practice..whew should be vewy intewesting hehe....gotta go clean some stuff now...whew!

author: Bright Eyes
title: Gone, FANITO, good-bye
post_content: "Sniff... Sniff... Cough... Wahoo"Ahh long time no see. I gotta say I do still love my blog, it’s always there for yah even if you’ve neglected it... your few readers however... well the blog is still there though. Plus it doesn’t complain or ask for anything in return... except well id be pretty ticket is some blogger gave me a hideous layout with hearts and black and red font.My neglect comes with a good excuse sickness – Tegan and Sara concert – sickness – sickness. A) people who go shopping when their sick should be shot. The only thing they do is spread their disease around. Working in retail I have to continually wash my hands worried that the countless sick people that into the store during flu season will spread their disease. They fondle the merchandise and peruse the shelves – do they ever buy anything? no. Why? Because they are sick, they don’t care about decorating their home, they are just so tired of being sick they get bored and think, HEY i’m healthy enough to leave me home... WRONG. You are not, stay at home, get the rest of your family sick, I don’t know you, and I don’t want your germs. So it’s inevitable with my endless hand scrubbing that I would get sick. I would however understand it if they were shopping because they needed to buy a present or some urgent reason why they would leave their homes, but that’s never the case. So to all you sick people who go to movies, and go shopping, or to a restaurant while your sick STOP it you selfish wank.Moving on...    Tegan and Sara "Waahoo"  Last Wednesday was the Tegan and Sara concert at reds. It was fantastic it was the first time I had ever sent hem play live which is amazing because I have admired them since their hit “The First” got radio play. So Matt and myself trot out our houses around 5pm to go pick up the tickets that we ordered online months ago. When I got there the lady at ticket master said If I would have been a minute later my tickets would have been printed out at Reds, and given away to another customer... kind of a bullshit system if you think about it, and I still doubt that, that would be the case. So with the tickets in hand we headed to West Edmonton Mall only to look at the tickets to see the doors opened at 8pm. Since it was around 5:30 at the time I suggested we waited and went to Matt’s house to kill time there. Instead we went to the Mall thinking it would be better to kill time there... we were wrong. We ate yummy subs and then walked around mindlessly – since both Matt and I are broke it was a bit tedious. Now I really wish we went to Matt’s house just because walking around and then waiting in line only completely drained us of all energy (damn I’m getting old). We met some friends in line who were there and ahead in line (yes we butted I’m an ass get over it). We only had to wait about 30 minutes in line before they started to let people in. Little did we know reds went through the first 20 people in line and took their tickets ahead of time to stop people from budding sop when we got to the security the guy bumped us to the back of the line. So I was pissed right off, since the lined had progressed about 200 people back. So we waited about 30 more minutes again, by the time we made it back our other friends told us he took the tickets of the people behind us – so the guy was just having a power trip, and wanted to be an ass. That’s Red’s for yah.  The crowd in reds was pretty diverse, packed with teenage Emo kids and some older people around my age. So by this time I was getting pretty pumped, Reds played clips from America’s Funniest Home Video’s on their big screen while we waited, and finally Lindy came out to play. Now I don’t really understand why some band’s pick the openers they do. By rights an opener should get people pumped, not be too long, but long enough to expose their music and vibe to the crowd, entertain them for the time it takes to do so, and still get them pumped for the show ahead. Lindy did none of these things. There was little stage charisma, and their musical style seemed like wannabe Belle and Sebastian, the band itself spent more time looks at their instruments and the floor than conversing with the crowd. Their set seemed long and drawn out, leaving the crowd to converse with themselves and wonder when their suffering would end. Well, actually that’s been a little harsh; they weren’t horrible they just seemed like one of those bands that would be better via CD. SO by the time they were done, I was completely drained, having been standing for 4 hours now, and being old and sick. It was pretty neat to see both Tegan and Sara come out to watch Lindy play their set. I was so surprised to see how short they both were, which only made them look more cute. Plus you could completely get the vibe that they don’t think their huge celebrities with ego, they had no problem coming out to watch their opener. So once they got on set all my tiredness and aches went away and was replaced with musical bliss. All I have to say is wow. I was so happily surprised at how great they sounded live, even better than they do on album. They seem to be able to play anything from electric guitar to keyboards and acoustic. Both the twins switched in and out during their set between instruments. Reds however has some sound issues and their techies had some mic issues, so the fact that they sounded amazing over all that I was extremely impressed. They carried themselves on stage with perfection. They have immense charisma with their band mates and themselves. Plus they carry and aura towards their fans that they are truly grateful for the support and had mentioned many times throughout the show that, that was indeed the case. Apparently that show was the biggest crowd they had played too that was just them headlining, which I thought was pretty neat. I also thought it was pretty cool when someone yelled out a song request from the crowd and mentioned it was their Birthday, so Tegan got everyone in the crowd to yell happy birthday until she saw everyone yell. Comparing them to other female artists I had seen live they treat each and every fan as if they would treat a friend, they have absolutely no ego, which makes their live shows quite enjoyable. Especially because you don’t need all that crap, you don’t need rehearsed “talking to the crowd bits” they talked naturally, and once they played you saw their passion for the music which must be so hard to do night after night playing the same songs. They do it in a way that you believe that they make music that they love, and it makes u love it even more. I would love to see what a cd with the production quality that Jennifer Lopez gets staring T&amp;S because their live range was amazing, and it just doesn’t show on their albums.Their set was a mix of new and old, with quite a variety. They also finished the show with a song I had never heard before which was a treat. All in all I give it a 5 star show. not only am I thankful I got the chance to see them live, but also that there is someone out there so talented that actually has a fan base that allows them to make music. They are only going to get bigger and bigger, whether or not they ever make a huge success in the Much Music world. Go see them now. Check out their site for the rest of Canadian tour dates, and get all your friends to go with.Official Siteps. “I told u so” – Grammy awards (friggin U2)-J

author: CalgaryWineGuy
title: Okanagan Wine Trip '07 - Day 1
post_content: Day 1 - May 25thWell, here we go again for my annual jaunt through the Okanagan wine country.  Having done this twice before, I have a better feel for where to go, where not to go, and how to pace my trip.Armed with my trusty laptop, this time around I can blog as I go and give you daily updates - just like a real journalist would!I left Calgary just after 10AM.. After a quick stop in Golden for some lunch, I made it into the Okanagan around 4:00PM local time.. Since it was early enough and it was on the way, I figured I'd stop in at Arrowleaf cellars - a great way to start my trip, being that they're one of my favorite wineries here..I tasted about 5 of the usual suspects:White Feather - their house white blend - a nice quaffable white - not a lot of depth here, but great for patio season.Red Feather - my favorite wine here - their Rose blend - after some sweet-talking, I managed to get my hands on a half a case of the as yet unreleased 2006 vintage (already a silver medal winner) - primarily Pinot Noir and Chardonnay this year.   Looking forward to the hot weather to drink some of this!Chardonnay - a decent Okanagan chard - very little oak, unlike so many of the bottles coming out of CaliforniaSolstice - their red blend, primarily Merlot and Zweigelt.. I wasn't blown away, but I'm usually not by their reds.  They just seem better at the whites and rose.Vidal (I cant remember the name - its new for them) - it's an off-dry white - the grapes are picked at the same time as the one they use for their late-harvest vidal, so you can guess that the sugar content is pretty high to start with.  I assumed that they fermented it for a bit longer to get the excess sugar out - this seemed to be confirmed by the relatively high 13.6% alcohol content..All in all, I walked out of Arrowleaf with a case of wine for myself and some friends..After Arrowleaf, I headed straight into downtown Kelowna to check into the Royal Anne Hotel - I like this hotel - reasonably priced, and just a block from the waterfront.  And - it's a nice 5 block walk away from...Bouchons Bistro.  Ahhhh...Once again, my love affair with this restaurant has been rekindled for another year.  I walked in a little before 7, and as always, the owner / Maitre'd was out front to greet me - showed me to a table on the patio.  Over the next 90 minutes, I was back in culinary heaven..   I started out with French onion soup simmered with Chablis, paired up with a glass of Alstian Geuwurtztraminer.   Following that was a duo of duck leg confit, with some mushrooms sauteed with pork belly, some seasonable vegetables, and of course the obligatory pommes frites (this is a brasserie style restaurant after all).. I paired that up with a glass of Quail's Gate Reserve Pinot Noir, which worked nicely.   I followed up the main course with a chilled lavendar souflee with passionfruit puree, paired up with a glass of their house sauternes.   Add on an espresso, and I was 'fini'.I followed up that fabulous meal with a trip to the casino.. I think I will now write a book of my experiences, titled "How to lose at blackjack like a professional".. Up until tonight, I didn't think it would be possible to lose so much money while holding 19 or 20 in your hand.  Fortunately, the other gents at the table were having similar luck.So, now its time to retire for the evening, and prepare for Day 2.   Saturday is my day to conquer the southern Okanagan, and hopefully squeeze in a couple more good meals to boot.Cheers!

author: Timmo
title: Ride Me, Dazzler
post_content: Game 14... Tues Aug 9th, 2005It was a game that the Dazzlers more-or-less needed to win against the first place Panthers. A victory wouldn't guarantee promotion to the next division, but a loss would more-or-less knock it on the head.But the omens weren't great from the beginning: nervous emails flying around in the hours running up to the match;uncharacteristic squabbling out on the field in the first few innings; Isaac cracking his rib just a few days before; the trip down to south London which always seems to send everyone's internal compass doo-lally as soon as they cross the river; plus the Yankees not being able to get a handle on those damn Bosox... it all proved too much, even for a Dazzlers team that arrived early for some pre-game warm-up and practice, riding high on the wave of an exciting win the week before.And so, against the background of sun-kissed young lovers sunbathing and frolicking shamelessly on an unusually beautiful evening as the streaming sunshine blazed through the leaves and onto the rich green grass of Clapham Common, the team took the field to... come to think of it, what the hell were we doing playing softball in the first place???The details aren't important. In fact, it's probably better not to go into them. The mishandled ground balls, the overthrows, the scoreless innings at the plate... whatever. There were some bright spots, like Amy's sizzling liner down the 3rd base line in the top of the 1st; Sam's sky-high tape-measure shot to left field that almost hit the Space Shuttle on its way back down to earth; Rob's fantastic grab in deep, deep right-center field (even if it was obviously only due to the magic little pair of white shoes that he had just put on).Mostly, though, it seems all a blur. And an unfair end to what had been a great season, in an unexpectedly competitive division. But if it is any compensation, it wasn't just that the Dazzlers got beat by a better team. There was a little bit more poetry in it than that. The opposing first-place Panthers were the development team the year before Tony and Gerard put the Dazzlers together. They had that little bit of extra seasoning that the Dazzlers will hopefully pick up next year. They were one year more mature, been round it one extra loop, this was their 3rd stab at it. Their time had come. They were ready to reap the benefits of the hard work they had invested, the experience they had accumulated. I mean, c'mon. they're a great bunch of people and they deserved it, didn't they? Ah, um, didn't they...?Finsbury Dazzlers 3 1 3 0 0 0 1 - 08Sumatra Panthers 8 3 4 6 1 4 x - 26

author: Yashar Ahad Saremi
title: مکالمه ی جادویی در راه هلیوپولیس
post_content: براي محسن بني فاطمهكسي در زد. باز صداي در بلند بلند .. . چه حين نا به هنگامي براي در زدن...ـ كه هستي ؟ـ منم !يك زن پشت در ايستاده بود.خواستم بگويم .. كه گفتم : برگرد !در را دوباره زد آن زن ،ـ باز كن اين در را !عقربه ها را نگريستم . يخ زمانِ من داشت اندك اندك آب مي شد و نورهاي شهر از دورترهاي روحم سو سو مي زدند. يك ساعت براي زندگي داشتم . شبيه عقيقي در آب . نگاه كردم ديوارهاي آشنا را .ديوارها گفتند : برگرد زن !زن لب‌هايش را به در چسبانيد .ـ در را باز كن اي گيج گول ..چه وقت ديري ! خواستم بگويم ..ـ برگرد !در را دوباره زد در را باز كردم . او مرا پيرمردي با دستاني لرزان ، شالي بر گردن و خميده و پريشان ديد ، من او را تازه و سبز پوشيده ، 19 ساله با لب هايي كبود و جاي سرخ گلوله در سينه ، درست طرف چپ سينه ديدم ..ـ ها . تو اويي ؟ـ منم .ـ چهل و اندي سال پيش مرده بود او . رفته بود او .ـ آن رفته هرگز نمرده بود در .. .ـ برگرد !ـ جاي و كجايي ندارم. همه گانم رفته اند . شهر خاموش است و برف مي بارد !ـ آرزويت را بگو !ـ ها ، تا يك ساعت ديگر تو هم رفته خواهي شد. آمده ام دستت را وا بگيرم با هم برويم .ـ ديوانه ، پريشاني نكن. چهل و اندي سال پيش من تو را كشتم . دستانم را نگاه كن ، اين لرزش از كابوس آن شب است .خنديد. سرد خنديد . لرزاند مرا از اين خندهـ شهر مرا كشت . آدم ها مرا كشتند . زبان ها مرا كشتند . مثله مثله شدم در ويرانه ها و تاريكي ها . ياد شدم و باد شدم. اما ذهن تو هنوز جاي بكر و خنكي بود برايم . در آن جا نشستم به زندگي جادويي خود ادامه دادم .ـ ها ، اي روح طاووس ها برگرد . مرا با اين پريشان گويي ها آزار مده. برگرد تا من بروم . برگرد تا من بروم چهره ام را رنگ كنم .دستي به صورتم كشيد. در چشم هايم خيره شد .ـ پيرمرد آرامش داشته باش!دستم را گرفت و داخل خانه آمد. بيرون خانه برف مي باريد و سخت هم مي باريد. چراغ را خاموش كرد و نشست . روبرويش نشستم. عقربه ها و صداي عقربه ها .ـ اول من مي روم !صورتم را كه رنگ مي كرد ، خنديد . مثل همه ي معشوقه ها خنديد .ـ با هم مي رويم !ـ آن روزها تو ترانه اي دلنشين مي خواندي !صورتم را طلايي و سرخ كرد . خواند.« نه يدين گوزه ليم سن گوزه ليم ، دون گئجه نه يدين ؟ » من با او ترانه را تكرار كردم . دستانم را در سفيد فرو برد . گريه ام گرفته بود . انگار مرا به ختنه مي بردند . گفتم : ...ـ مرا چرا كشتي ؟دست هايم را برداشت و بر قلبش گذاشت . درست همان جايي كه گلوله ي طلايي در آن نشسته بود و سوخته بود و پيچيده بود و پرنده را پرانده بود. با خود انديشيدم كه ها ، چرا او را كشتم ؟ يادم نيامد هيچ ! صورتش را ان قدر نزديك آورد كه فقط دهانش را ديدم كه ...ـ لبخند بزن در اين صورت درخشان !ـ ها ، چه دير . چه تلخ !انگشتش را بر سينه ام گذاشت . تاريكي درخشيد و گلوله اي چرخيد و پيچيد و سينه ام را دريد . قلبم از نوك سرد عقربه افتاد و افتاديم ....در باز شد و چند نفر از برف آمدند و پادشاه و ملكه را برداشتند و بردند .28 نوامبر 1998 / لوس آنجلس / كافه ي لولوس

author: Eeyore
title: I can't believe I've not updated for so long!
post_content: Sorry I've not updated for so long! It really is most shameful of me, and I'm sure you won't make do with the excuse that I've been very busy! I will try and remember as much as I can of what has happened since my last post, but those of you who know me well will know that my memory isn't the best in the world, so forgive me if I leave anything out and have to edit the post at a later date!I guess the main bit of news since my last update is that a couple of weeks ago, I was rejected without an interview from the university of my dreams, Oxford. I was absolutely devastated at the time, though I'm beginning to see it in a more philosophical light now. I was at school when I got the news; first thing on a Friday morning, and we'd been let out of English early, so I went to the common room, which thankfully was nearly empty. I got a text from my dad saying that a letter had arrived from Lincoln College, so I phoned him and asked him to open it and read it out to me. Imagine, if you will, how stunned I was when he read out the words:"Unfortunately, in view of the overall competition for places this year and after consultation with other colleges, I am sorry to have to tell you that we shall not be able to offer you a place at Oxford and that your application is no longer under consideration by any of the colleges here."My initial reaction was to think that it was some kind of awful joke on my dad's part. But no, that would be too cruel. The next thing I did was to burst into tears, run out of the common room, sign out of school ill and wander in a dazed, aimless fashion in the direction of the station (still crying my eyes out and attracting some weird looks from passers-by), to go home. I phoned Alan, who was too shocked to say anything. I didn't stop crying for about an hour and a half. I phoned Jason, who was very supportive and sympathetic and advised me to go out and buy a new pair of shoes, which I did.Change of font colour as it's now over two months since I wrote the above! My lovely Alan is in Japan for *five weeks* and the time difference means that we don't get to talk very much, and thus I have time on my hands and am resurrecting this blog. More on that later, in the meantime I had better update you with what's been going on since that fateful day when I was rejected from Oxford!My teachers did all they could to try and persuade Lincoln College to give me an interview, but alas, to no avail. It was a sad day when we finally had to give up hope, but with hindsight I'm feeling more philosophical about it - in a way, I'm quite relieved that I didn't have to go through the pressure of the infamous Oxford interview, not to mention that if I had got in, I would probably have got very fed up with the amount of work after a while. I'm glad I won't have to go through all that stress, when going to university will be stressful enough as it is.I have had offers from Reading and York, a rejection from Warwick (more on this later!), and I'm still waiting to hear from Durham and Nottingham. My plan initially was to take a year out and reapply to Cambridge, but I've now realised that would be a waste of time, and having been on an open day to Reading University, I've decided to go there. I don't need GCSE Spanish to go there, so I've dropped that and now I get to come home at 11.30am on Thursdays (as opposed to 5.15pm!), which is brilliant! The good thing about Reading is that I can live with Alan whilst doing my degree, which will be excellent. Again, more on this later!The main event since then has been my trip to France over the Christmas holidays. That was quite an experience! Having said goodbye to Alan (always a horrid moment) when he went to France before Christmas, I then joined him in France on December 28, sailing from Portsmouth to St Malo on a cheap overnight crossing. Remarkably, I managed to find my way around the ferry without getting lost, and I met Alan at St Malo the next morning without event. We went to Mt St Michel (I would post photos if I knew how!), a lovely kind of island thing joined to the mainland, with a monastery on top. There was a small street winding round the island leading up to it, and the place had a great atmosphere, like the kind of place you might see on a Christmas card. Unfortunately, my enjoyment of it was hindered slightly by excruciating period pains, and I have a photo of me looking very glum sitting in the main chapel in great pain!That afternoon, we drove back to Alan's parents' place, which is near Vannes in Brittany. I was *so* nervous! I don't speak any French, and they don't speak any English, which just made it worse. I must confess that it took me several days before I started to relax, though there were moments when I was able to be myself a bit more (such as after dinner, when Alan's mum produced loads of Alan's baby photos - sooooo cute! And when Alan's brother, his wife, Alan and I played a kind of board game and I won, even though it was the first time I'd played... don't think Alan was too pleased, as he's played it lots of times but never won!).The food was rather an ordeal! I don't eat that much at the best of times, so faced with meals the size and richness of those, I was not a particularly happy bunny! Perhaps the worst moment for me in terms of food came when a bowl of shrimps arrived on the table. Whole shrimps, with their little eyes staring up at me. The idea was to pull their heads off (gross gross gross!), then peel the legs and shell off, before dipping them in mayonnaise and eating them like that. I was horrified, and looked round to see what everyone else was doing, and they were all tucking into them heartily, so I had no option but to do the same. I found the shells to be very weird, so that I couldn't tell whether they were really hot or really cold... or maybe it wasn't the nature of the shells, maybe it was just me. Anyhow, I was proud of how I handled them, gritting my teeth and bearing it, with bread to help them down. I'm not overly keen to eat them again though, I must say!After staying a couple of days in Vannes, we went to a little village called Binic, on the north coast of Brittany not far from St Malo. This is where Alan's sister and her family live, and where we stayed two nights to celebrate the New Year. The festivities commenced at around 8pm, when we had several courses of food (including more shrimps, alas!) which I thought would never end, culminating in ice cream served with a liqueur which is meant to help you digest quickly so that you can go on eating more! Alan's sister and I didn't have any of that as we don't drink alcohol, but everyone else did. I couldn't believe that! I was relieved, then, when at about 11.30pm we went for a walk to the beach to let off some fireworks. I needed a break from all that eating! The kids were really excited and were being very noisy, and I frankly just wanted to spend some time alone with Alan! We couldn't though, which kind of pissed me off to be honest, but nevermind. After midnight, we went walking round the village, the kids yelling "bonne année" all the way. I thought people would get annoyed with them, but a guy leant out of his window and shouted "bonne année" back to us!  It was a great atmosphere, and certainly my most memorable New Year's Night so far.When we got back, it was loud music, the kids going insane dancing to it, and then more food. By this time I was beginning to get really rather pissed off, as I was tired, I'd already eaten far too much food, and I really wanted to be alone with Alan. But no, I had to endure several more courses, and by the time we eventually got to bed at about 3am, I was exhausted and as soon as we were behind closed doors I started crying again, *is ashamed of self*. To add insult to injury, we were sleeping on a horrid old camp bed, which took ages to pump up and then gradually deflated over the next few hours meaning that we had to get up in the middle of the night to pump it up again. Not only that, but every single tiny movement one made produced a massive noise! I think they must have given it to us as some kind of joke!The next day we slept in until about 1pm, which was a source of amusement for Alan's family. I forget how we spent the afternoon, but as some people left I remember beginning to feel a bit more relaxed, and having fun with Alan's nephews and niece. In the evening after the kids had gone to bed, we adults sat down for a meal (yes, more food!!), only for the lights to start switching on and off before finally not coming back on at all! Looking out the window, the entire village appeared to have had the power cut too, so everywhere was pitch black! This was soon followed by the children getting upset, because they were frightened of the dark. Alan's sister and her husband managed to find some candles, and we sat down by candlelight (was actually really quite romantic!) to continue eating. Typically, having spent some minutes lighting all those candles, the electricity returned a couple of minutes later and the lights came back on!The following morning we said goodbye to Alan's sister and her family and started the bit I was really looking forward to - the journey to Paris. Six hours or so of time spent just the two of us! On the way there, we drove through Versailles, which was absolutely awesome! It was dark by the time we got there, and the palace was lit up and looked fabulous - I definitely want to go back for a proper visit some day! The streets were all lit with Christmas lights, and it looked wonderful.We arrived at Alan's brother's house a little later that evening, and I liked it because it was a lot quieter following the noise of Alan's sister's kids (though don't get me wrong, they were great - just in moderation!)! We spent those last two days in Paris, which is the best city I've ever been to (but I agree, I've not visited that many!). We saw lots of very famous places, and I was ashamed of myself for acting like a tourist and getting all excited over seeing the Eiffel Tower for the first time! We went right to the top, and the view was breathtaking! We then went to the top of the Arc de Triumph, which was considerably harder work than the lifts which take one to the top of the Eiffel Tower - it was a spiral staircase, which seemed to go up, and up, and up forever! I had the misfortune of having hiccups all the way up too, so there was me out of breath and the sound of my hiccups resonating through the stairwell thanks to the stone walls and floor! However, the struggle up those stairs was worth it for the spectacular view of Paris by night, including the Eiffel Tower lit up! It was really wonderful, and I didn't want to leave!Other places we went to in Paris included Montmatre, which had an amazing atmostphere, what with the guy sitting playing the harp (gave the place such an air of culture!) and all the artists waiting to paint/draw people's portraits. The view of Paris from there was spectacular, too. We went round Notre Dame cathedral, which was also very impressive, as well as seeing the Moulin Rouge (from the outside). The street which the Moulin Rouge is on is extremely dodgy, as it is lined with sex shops - more than I've ever seen in my life! (ok, confession time... I don't think I'd ever seen a sex shop before then! :-0) I actually felt quite scared to be there after dark (we had to so that we could take photos of the Moulin Rouge when it's all lit up... though we took some pics of the sex shops too, just because there were so many!)!I'm sure there are other things I meant to write about Paris - it was certainly a packed couple of days! I loved Paris and didn't want to leave - two days weren't long enough, that's for sure! I hope to go back some day, though in the meantime there are many, many other places I'd like to visit, so I won't waste time by revisiting somewhere I've already been for now! We managed to get an earlier ferry home to England, sailing from Calais, though it was in the middle of the night and the ferries were running late due to adverse weather conditions. Once on board, we headed for one of the lounges, where having had a cup of hot chocolate Alan went to sleep, and I was left not really knowing what to do, as I hadn't thought of bringing a book, and I'm not fortunate enough to be able to sleep whenever and wherever I want! I had a look round some of the shops on the ferry, and made the mistake of trying on some perfumes. Why was this a mistake, I hear you ask? I'm sure it would have been fine had it been the daytime (ie, had I been able to see outside so that I could see the motion of the ship), but as it was the middle of the night I couldn't see the horizon, and whilst initially the up and down movement of the ship thanks to the rough sea was fairly exciting, the novelty soon wore off and I began to feel very sick. The heady smell of the perfume just made me feel ten times worse, and as soon as we were back in the car, I washed it off with bottled water! I shan't be making that mistake again!My overall feelings about the trip were good: it was quite an experience, and there were some very memorable moments. I did wish on many occasions, however, that I had been able to spend more time alone with Alan, as we did in Cornwall. It was great to meet his family at last, despite the communication problems, but given the choice I would certainly have opted for a holiday for just the two of us! We are planning on going to Italy over the summer, which I'm greatly looking forward to. I really want to see the world!I had better say a few words about one or two things which happened before I left for France! My dad took my friend Hannah and me to see Handel's Messiah in Bath just before Christmas, which we both enjoyed greatly. It was nice to see so many people I know (including the evil guy I dated a few times a couple of years ago, Nathan; though he was pretty charming on that particular occasion), in particular Jason (who was conducting) and my best friend from choir, Claire. I loved the music, and it was nice to go to a concert as a member of the audience for a change!The end of term at school didn't really feel like the end of term, and was distinctly lacking in the Christmas spirit which had been such a feature of the previous year. This was because our sadistic headteacher banned anything to do with Christmas, even down to tinsel in the hair, even on the very last day of term. He also limited the number of carols sung in the end of term assembly to one (Hark the Herald Angels Sing, a nice religious one), which was not met with popular approval. I played in the band and happily occupied the role of principal flute, a pleasant improvement on last year when my arch nemesis Katherine took on the role. The day after the end of term my friends and I went to Gill's 18th birthday party, which was basically just a pizza and video evening and swapping Christmas presents. I didn't enjoy it much, as I never really enjoy being in groups of more than three or four people. I find it intimidating!Corsley Choir is going well. Our concert at the beginning of December seemed to be a success, though I must admit I found the repertoire rather boring. Natalie came to the concert, and I introduced her to the famous John. I was in turn introduced to John's wife and John's wife's mother, and I found that his wife was really nice! I've since come to the conclusion that John seems more of a family man than he likes to make out sometimes, and he's finally learnt to kiss me on the cheek and not on the lips. So good progress there! We are now singing the Mozart Requiem (and will be singing the Ave Verum too), which I'm really excited about. I'm finding it harder than I expected, but I love the music so much that I don't find that problematic in the slightest! I have also been getting on well with Jason recently, although Rachel has had to tell him off for being too sarcastic with me (he claims I find it funny because I always laugh, which sadly is true... he is funny!)!I suppose the most major event before France was Christmas, which was enjoyable (though I would have liked to have been with Alan on Christmas Day, but nevermind! I hopefully will be this year!). My uncle Michael came on the day as he usually does, so that was fun. We went for a nice walk with the dog and took lots of photos, and in the evening watched a film (I can't remember what it was we watched!). On Boxing Day some old neighbours of ours came for lunch, which is something they always do and something which I personally find rather a bore.A notable absence from the Christmas festivities was my grandparents. This is because we are unfortunately no longer on good terms with them. Entirely their choice, and sparked off by events which began with the death of my great grandmother. My mum and I represented our part of the family at the funeral in November, and while we were there we met lots of relatives (many of whom I never knew existed) with whom we decided we would like to remain in contact. This appeared to be Grandad's intention too, for the relatives in question are his brothers (my great uncles), who have been estranged for many years for various reasons too complicated to go into. To cut a long story short, Nanny had other ideas, and very soon she had taken offence at my mum wanting to be on friendly terms with Grandad's brothers, and announced that they would not be spending Christmas with us, which they have done for as long as I can remember. Since then things have escalated, and they've announced that they're not going to speak to us again, which I frankly find ridiculous and hurtful. I never expected to fall out with them, and it's a great pity. They seem determined not to listen to any talk from us of reconciliation, and it seems that they have made their minds up and there is nothing we can do about it. So that's that! :-(January was very busy, what with revising for my geography resit exam. I spent a free period with Mrs Hand, who very kindly gave me a file and organised all my geography notes for me, so that I knew which ones I had to revise from (otherwise I'd have wasted time revising for stuff which wouldn't come up on the paper!). In the end, I don't know how the exam went - one never can tell! - but I'm not too bothered about it because I still got a B overall, and if it's any worse than last time I don't need to take the grade, I can keep the first one. At the end of January I went to Warwick University for an interview, which went disasterously. I didn't like the interviewer and she (why couldn't it have been a guy, they're so much easier to talk to!) clearly didn't like me, and asked lots of questions which didn't leave much scope for very stimulating replies, not to mention that she asked me about a book I'd mentioned in my personal statement which I hadn't finished reading, so I couldn't talk about it at all because she was asking about the ending. All in all it was a disaster, and I ended up disliking the university as a whole owing to that unpleasant experience. I didn't stay for the sample lectures, I just went straight home! As predicted I was rejected, and it's just a good job I didn't want to go there!My job at the cafe I mentioned is going well. I'm still doing it, remarkably (I've been wanting to leave), though I do find it very hard work and stressful. It's rather making me appreciate Longleat! Incidentally, I did get that bonus I spoke of in my last entry! £108! They also paid me £120 of holiday pay, so that was great - it worked out really well in the end! My mum applied for a job there this year, but sadly didn't get the job because there were an incredible thirty applicants just for six places! I don't think it can have been that competitive last year, when I was applying for the job, otherwise I doubt I would have got the job.At the beginning of this month (February) I had my A level recital, which was traumatic. I played the Telemann Viola Concerto, Glasunow "Elegie" (also for viola) and "Idylle" by Benjamin Godard (for flute), and Gerry, the guy who accompanies Corsley Choir, accompanied me, which was great as I get on very well with him. The recital could have gone worse, but it could also have gone a lot better. My viola playing really let me down, and the question on everyone's lips after the recital was why didn't I do the whole recital on the flute! The answer being that I was advised by people who know better than me about these things not to do the recital on the flute, since I no longer have lessons. Let's face it, I hadn't played the flute properly for over a year, and yet my playing was still infinitely superior to my viola playing, despite having lessons most weeks. I have no decided I'm going to do the recital again, but entirely on the flute, and I'm having a flute lesson with Jonathan as a birthday present from my parents (it's horrendously expensive) in order to help me prepare. I'm quite excited about that!The state of my health has been somewhat less exciting. My cough having returned, I began to experience a shortness of breath about which I went to see the doctor and was then diagnosed with some kind of asthma. I now have to have an inhaler, which is a pain, and some time in the next few days I will be having to go to the hospital to have a chest x-ray, which is annoying. I just hope it doesn't reveal anything potentially nasty!It was half term last week and I spent the week with Alan, naturally. I went to his place on Friday night, but unfortunately came down with a really severe fever, and spent the whole of the next day and much of Sunday as well in bed. On Monday it was Valentine's Day, and Alan and I went to collect the gorgeous ring he has bought me, which was very exciting! It's a pink sapphire gem with a diamond either side, and I'm still captivated by the way it sparkles in the light! In the afternoon, we dressed up in smart clothes (he looked absolutely gorgeous in his suit.... I felt so proud to be with him!) and set off somewhere (I didn't, at that point, know where we were going!). It turned out that we were going to London, to a Valentine's concert given by the London Concert Orchestra at the Barbican Hall! It was tremendously exciting, although I got very cold on the streets of London and my shoes weren't the most comfortable in the world! It was worth it though, and it was a super evening. We even made it back to Oxford in time to go to Domino's Pizza before it closed at midnight, hurrah!The rest of the week, Alan had to be at work during the day, so I worked on my coursework back in his room, which was boring and claustrophobic, but worth it to be able to spend the evenings and nights together. I can assure you, however, that you do *not* want to get me started on the subject of his landlady, so I shall say no more about her than that. Last Wednesday, we went to look at an apartment in Abingdon, just south of Oxford, and decided very quickly that it's the place for us, so we've reserved it! It's so exciting! It's a really nice top floor apartment with a great kitchen, and we'll be moving into it when it becomes available in May (though I won't be able to live there until the end of May when I go on study leave, but it's only a few weeks!). I shall then be commuting from Abingdon to Reading when I'm at university. It's all happening at the moment! :-DExcept that technically, it's not all happening, since Alan is in Japan for five weeks. He left on Saturday and won't be back until March 27th (when I will be meeting him at Heathrow), which, though exciting for him, is almost unbearable for me because we hardly get to talk at all because of the time difference (Japan is nine hours ahead) and because he only gets internet access when he's at work. I can't believe it's going to be so long before I see him again... in fact, it seems like an eternity. I've felt really depressed over the last few days, and I didn't expect to find this so difficult to cope with. I think I'm beginning to come to terms with it, but the prospect of the next few weeks seems frightfully gloomy (in particular when he leaves Kyoto and will only have internet access sporadically... his phone doesn't work in Japan, so we'll be totally without means of communication). *sigh* It's really testing me to the limits, and on top of everything else I'm kind of jealous that he gets to travel to so many interesting places.... I just really hope I will be as lucky some day.It has been snowing here a lot today, and BBC News Online (a site to which I've been addicted since Alan left because I've got nothing else to do) informs me that the worst is yet to come. I really crave somewhere warm at the moment, or at the very least I crave the arrival of summer!I shall sign off here, for this entry is now ridiculously long; congratulations if you have made it this far! I'll try and update again soon.

author: DomAbr
title: Installed XP SP2 - hold thumbs
post_content: Ok, so like the rest of the sentient universe I'm playing Oblivion. Lots of fun and I wont even try to review it here. But what is it missing, multiplayer? Well no, the genius behind Oblivion is the very nature of the single player experience. But after playing World of Warcraft and getting used to being *part* of a community thats what I really miss. Playing Oblivion feels lonely.Has WoW ruined single player games for me? Has the feeling of belonging to a Guild ruined the enjoyment of a lone experience? And solo questing doesnt count as a truly lone experience - I'd estimate that a very large percentage of all inter-personal interaction between players on WoW is not directly related to the quest or adventure being played by the people chatting away. People chat about how to beat a mob, or how cool your latest gear is, perhaps discuss raid tactics or your latest spec lists. Often the conversation mutates into interesting but nonetheless unrelated topics such as your latest gadgets, where you're going on holiday or what your favourite artist is up to. Thats the thing - its a communityPerhaps WoW has ruined single player games. But how about this - introduce the feeling of an online community into the existing Oblivion game using a 'chat' mod. Imagine playing Oblivion but having access to a similiar type of chat function as in WoW. Form and join guilds, interact online with friends while playing Oblivion, get tips on the quests and the world....think of it as WoW but in a very large 1 player instance.I reckon that would be fun, and if some intrepid developer comes up with the mod, I'll pay a dollar for it!
