author: LTB
title: NAACP: Allow the "Invisible Hand" to Help Right Wrongs
post_content: Recently the Commission on Civil Rights announced they will analyze whether minorities and women deserve preferences in federal government contracting (see story). Because this is such an emotional subject, I can foresee both ends of the political spectrum making this a polarizing issue. Liberals will maintain that conservatives are trying to eliminate economic opportunities for minorities; conservatives will insist that preferences in contracting is not only unfair, but actually undermines some of the basic principles civil rights advocates fought and died for.As an economist who leans neither left or right politically, I hope the Commission will look at the issue from an economic standpoint. Specifically, I would hope their study would analyze and address the following questions:Overall, has government contracting preferences benefits for exceeded its costs? If so, how?How has preferential programs like 8(a) benefited the minority community over the long run? What percentage of minority firms receiving preferential contracts have also developed successful opportunities in the private sector? How have these minority firms affected distressed households and communities? In my opinion, if minority (and other) firms that has received preferential federal contracts have helped increased economic opportunity in distressed communities where they otherwise would not have occurred, then contracting preferences by race and/or gender benefits may outweigh its costs. However, if these contracting preferences do not help "lift all boats", then contracting preference by race is an economic cost to this country that does the most harm to those it was initially intended to help.

author: Stone
title: Tunnel Vision
post_content: Half the lights in the lab aren't working. To my left, it's a little dim, a little brighter to the right. The right. She sits to the right. Smooth, brown-black hair tucked into a comfortable-looking ponytail. Mumbling equations and theorems to herself, scratching her temples occasionally. Her bright red sweater stares at me, as if it has a personality of its own. I stare at it, trying not to be too overwhelmed by its stare, its radiance. The ponytail bobs up and down as she shuffles to turn the page, I stare, mesmerized. She curls her feet around one another, her legs aching for some comfort as the digital clock at the bottom of the computer screen crawls towards 5 am. The pen nestled in her hand shuffles over the paper. Everything seems mast.She releases her breath in a gentle sigh, turning the page. I hold mine.

author: Mystery Editor
title: War Based Equality
post_content: BANG. BITE. RIP. SPIT.Fighting for the WBA Heavyweight Title in 1997 against Evander Holyfield, feeling desperate knowing his winning days were over, Mike Tyson bit Holyfield’s ear assuring a boxing legacy best described as bazaar.Like Tyson, the National Federation for the Blind (NFB) is feeling desperate as its 20 plus year hold on the Rehabilitation Services Administration (RSA) Commissioner post is slipping away. With their own gnashing of teeth, some NFB members that fed from the RSA trough for years have filed suit claiming discrimination because five of the 66 RSA staff being laid off are blind. Rumor has it that RSA regional staff without disabilities are considering suing as well claiming discrimination because after working at RSA they are perceived to have a disability.People with disabilities witnessing the RSA theater, wish that RSA staff would have advocated with equal vigor for their interest.

author: Jeremy Brindlethorpe
title: Why the Iraq Prison debacle is Nixon's fault
post_content: Many of those who are seeking to preserve the life of Terri Schiavo cannot be  faulted for their position. Her parents, certainly are deserving of sympathy; it is surely difficult for them to let her go when they have tended to her so lovingly for so long.Perhaps they are victims of wishful thinking in claiming to see evidence of responsiveness on her part where none exists, but for this, too, they cannot be faulted -- this is a natural human tendency. If someone I loved were seriously ill and I thought there was still a medical chance of successful treatment, I, too, would do everything in my power to pursue it, even over the objections of other family members, of medical professionals, and of courts.From an impersonal standpoint, there are four major ethical issues at stake: First, there is the question of Terri's cognitive state, second, there is the question of patient rights to self-determination, third, there is the question of who should be empowered to make major medical decisions in the absence of clear statements of patients wishes, and fourth, there is the question of financial costs.Regarding Terri's cognitive state, although the overall consensus of neurologists who examined Terri is that she is in a persistent vegetative state (PVS) and thus unaware of her surroundings, unresponsive to stimuli, and insensitive to pain and discomfort, there may be legitimate ground for dissent on this point. The brain often exhibits great neural plasticity, readapting to compensate for some very serious injuries. Regarding Terri's right to decide her own fate: According to Terri's husband, Terri epressed a wish not to be kept alive in circumstances where she was wholly dependent on others for her most basic needs. If, in fact, these were her wishes, it seems she, like other patients, should have the right to refuse treatment. The problem here is that (a) not everyone is persuaded that these were, in fact, her wishes (there is nothing in writing indicating such wishes), and (b) people will sometimes SAY that they would not wish to receive treatment in some condition only to change their minds when the envisioned scenario becomes a reality.Third, regarding proxy decisions: from a legal standpoint, those who support removing life-sustaining devices from Terri are on firm footing. Courts have repeatedly determined that a spouse should be the primary consultant regarding a patients wishes when the patient is unable to express his/her own wishes. Still, it is at least morally tragic when the wishes of the spouse conflict with other members of the patient's family, as is the case with Terri Schiavo.Fourth, regarding costs: It is easy to dismiss this as a morally irrelevant concern. Ideally everyone should receive unlimited medical treatment irrespective of costs. This is not, however, a reality. The reality is that in a world of limited resources, expenditures for one may deprive another of desired or needed resources. This is why it is important to determine whether Terri could stand to benefit in a meaningful way from continued treatment. This is a decision best made by medical professionals. But here, too, the refusal of courts to allow reinvestigation of Terri's condidtion render problematic the claim that she could not benefit from continued treatment. Of course, some assessments have been made, and at some point one must forego further assessments and reassessments and act on the information one has already gathered. Acting on Terri's case calls out for articulation of a general rule by which other, similar cases are to be decided. This is all the more important because of the reality that precludes continued treatment for all patients suffering similar injuries.Conclusion: The case here is not straightforward. It is definitely tricky; tricky enough that dogmatic conclusions either for or against ending her treatment are ill-advised. Going forward with any option ought, it seems to me, to be done with a reasonable measure of uncertainty regarding the moral status of one's decision. Significant moral decisions should rarely, if ever, be made from a standpoint of dogmatic arrogance.

author: Bernadette
title: Mundane week=over!
post_content: Well it's finally mid winter break, which is always a good time to just chill and catch up with people who i haven't seen in forvever. it's kind of amusing how things don't change at all sometimes.Ashley Murr nd I went out to dinner the other nite, and we're pretty much the same. I remember when we were like 8 and we played these lame games like try to make the other person laugh and we'd end up in complete hysterics no matter what, and well we almost always end up in hysterics no matter what. That's one thing I love about friends, no matter what happens, where you are, whatever the condtions they can always seem to make you feel better. Just so you all know I appriciate friends so much. Too bad I'm not hanging out with any now... oh wait my parents want me to be a hermit. I'm pretty convinvced of this fact actually. My Dad and I got in big fight like 2 days ago. He accused me of not caring about my family at all and all this other shit that's completely untrue, i think he honestly tries to piss me off sometimes. The main point of the fight was I should go out once every month and stay home cleaning and taking care of my sibs to show my true dedication to my family. Anyway, that kinda sucked, my break hasn't been bad by any streach tho. Saved is the funniest movie... I'm kinda in love with the gay guy in it, heh heh. I"M just so glad to not be at school, I"m getting like senioritis and I"m not even a senior. I seriously couldn't do any work the last week of school. Oh well. Hmm what else have I been doing? I think I write this just for myself, so i can figure out what's going on in my life i mean no one really reads it but that's ok... Well I won $105 dollars the other weekend in run for the roses. I got 3rd girl over all and sean and i won the couples race so we each got 50 for that. It was funny tho b/c when we went up to get our awards everytone thought we were together for real and was like awww. ha ha it made me laugh.ASo So I got to get some new shoes. and i'm already like stocking up on clothes for nexet year when i'm done wearing white polos. so i've done a lotta shopping. I wrote a letter to the editor yesterday about how CAFTA which the Bush administration is supporting is an idiotic idea, althought I didn't put it in those words. Well i'm gonna go. Thanks to all my friends, you keep me sane. ha love, bernadette

author: PowderPuff74
title: Is this the end?
post_content: How time flies, it seems ages since I last posted. After 24th of May, I just thought that, that was it. But it was not to be. The family's still intact and we're still together. The long walks and endless prayers paid off after all. I didn't turn up for the counselling session. But we're trying to work out on our own. One baby step at a time. It seems to be working, as long as I kept my demon out of the way. So much had happened. I guess it's a blessing in disguise, coz along the way it's the bits that's helping me to piece up the things together. Met a friend, whose case was far much agonizing than mine. It certainly made me realize that no matter how bad my situation are, others had it worse. We talked about devastated wife club and played with the idea to set up one LOL! Maybe who knows? Life's full of suprises, meanwhile, we're working on a project that will help us to fully utilize our time positively while in the healing process. So far so good ... as long as the demon's well caged.

author: erin
title: circle
post_content: ...and when it is over i will have a selective memory.it will edit the days that felt like this, it will patronize them.on the other side of this experience,i won't remember the severity.giving it other names and faces,i will lie outright.how is it that we come to romanticize our liveslike silent, scratchy films?i will catalogue this epic in frames and snatches,in just the way i had once anticipated it.justifying unbearable clouds for the sake of their glittering linings,and silvery tricks...the future is always calling, always promising redemption,and we learn to ignore our hearts' language.we choose to refuse the gravity of these moments.today i actually felt the sinking of a logged and heavy heart,tired and teary and finished with this place.yet i will forget,or i will pretend,and rush into a trapthat has already bled me.

author: Sam
title: Berg death welcome by U.S.
post_content: The execution of Nick Berg by his captors was most likley welcome news to the Bush administration. The goal is not to bring peace to the Muslim world but a sword. The U.S. war machine is being used as a tool by New World Order proponents to bring about change to the entire Middle East. This can only be done if tensions are kept high in the Middle East and here in the U.S.. The photos and news coming out of Abu Ghraib prison serve to stir up emotions on one side, while the killing and mutilation of contractors in Feluja and the execution of Nick Berg keep the flames fueled here in the U.S.. We should be weary of not falling into this trap as U.S. citizens. Larger forces are at work that go far beyond the fighting in Iraq. This war was planned well in advance of 9/11. I suggest that the abuses in Abu Ghraib prison were orchestrated to be leaked to the public. And were most likley approved by Donald Rumsfeld if not higher, again to keep tensions high. The real story here if reported Will Not be what went on in the prisons but, like Watergate, will be the coverup going on at this time. The execution of Nick Berg most likley also had either U.S. consent or outright participation by the CIA.

title: Done
post_content: So this is our web log of the bike trip.  We're hoping to leave on Monday, the 17th (my birthday!).  I'll be putting up a few "before" pictures as soon as the rest of our gear arrives (still waiting for some saddlebags, cycling socks, tires and tubes).  I'm not sure how often we'll be able to update this page, but I'm hoping to post an entry every few days or so, to let anyone know that we're still alive and how far along we are.  If you'd like to drop me an email, feel free to mail me at biketrip [atsign] supersharpshooter [dot] net.  I apologize for the incoherent formatting, but I want to keep my email from getting clogged with spam.  I suppose the next thing I'll do is post a list of the gear we're taking on the trip (as soon as we've collected all of it...).

author: Dan
title: WWDC update and more photos
post_content: It's been a long, but very beautiful drive up to San Francisco, taking HWY 1 most of the way.  I took some movies of the insane curves on that road that I'll post shortly.  We stopped at the Cable Car Barn to see all the machinery that pulls the cable cars around, and then drove up to Muir Woods to see the redwoods.  I was surprised how close the redwoods were to downtown SF.  On the way back, we stopped and walked out on the Golden Gate Bridge as the sun set, which was really cool.  It looks a LOT bigger when you're standing on it, and it has a very nice view of downtown SF.  The hotel I'm in is right downtown, and an OK place, but walking at night around this neighborhood is probably not the best idea, though we did anyway last night just to see it.  Mike left last night to go back home, and now I'm officially here on business!  The Apple WorldWide Developer's Conference starts tomorrow morning with a keynote speech by Steve Jobs, then all kinds of cool stuff goes on.

author: Gleice Cris
title: Fechada para balanço
post_content: O título dado a este 'projeto' é o que estou passando neste momento exato de minha vida: enclausurar-me com o destino de concluir algo após um auto exame escrupuloso, ou seja, permanecer por tempo indeterminado FECHADA PARA BALANÇO, Balanceando.Eu, há uns dias, estava no meu computador escrevendo um texto sobre tudo o que me levou a dar este passo, entretanto meu computador reagiu indevidamente com relação a isso, dando um 'tilt', antes que eu pudesse salvar o que escrevi. Fazendo assim com que eu perdesse tudo o que tinha datilografado, causando em mim uma dor incrível...Como certas coisas não dá para repetir eu estou meio reticente em escrever algo novamente pois seria como mastigar novamente algo que já foi deglutido. Ruminar. Creio que isso não me faria bem...é realmente uma pena.Contudo não vejo necessidade vital de compartilhar todos os motivos que me levaram a FECHAR PARA BALANÇO, talvez seja melhor assim...ridendo castigat moris...Enfim...primeiro post. Não sei se este blog continuará assim, mas até eu conseguir melhorar as coisas, ao menos, é excelente ter um local para escrever...

author: Mark Lindsey
title: Praising Grace, but why? Interrogating Ephesians 1:6
post_content: Ephesians 1:6to the praise of his glorious grace, with which he has blessed us in the Beloved.1. What can we learn about all the good in Ephesians 1:4-5 by the statement that it is done "to the praise of his glorious grace"?-- If predestination, or adoption, or his will is interpreted to put God in a bad light, YOU'RE DOING IT WRONG-- for example: if in explaining predestination you turn God into an unloving monster who makes children to die and burn in hell for eternity, and kind but ignorant, unevangelized pygmies who long for God but burn for never knowing the name Jesus, then YOU'RE DOING IT WRONG&gt;&gt;&gt; APPLICATION -- is the way and contexts that I talk about predestination, election, etc., TO THE PRAISE OF GOD's GRACE? Or is it argument? Divisive -- the insiders vs the unlearned? The pro-missions against the complacent?2. "With which he has blessed" We have been blessed with Grace. Or is it "blessed by grace?" Or is it "blessed using grace?" What does that mean? Is it called glorious grace because of greatness of the blessing?-- Ephesians 1:7 and 2:7 discuss "riches of his grace"3. What does it mean to be blessed IN the beloved?&nbsp;-- It parallels being adopted as sons THROUGH Jesus-- I suspect that there's a shade of difference in THROUGH Jesus vs IN Jesus.&nbsp;---- THROUGH Jesus might mean Jesus is a conduit to us---- IN Jesus might mean our only existence is our union with Jesus-- The difference is one of emphasis on our&nbsp;(a) blessings that come to us by way of Jesus, contrasted with&nbsp;(b) facts true of Jesus that become true of us when we are reconciled to Christ, and believe in him, and come to be IN Him.&gt;&gt;Adoption as sons IN Jesus would make sense mostly of Jesus were adopted. But Adoption THROUGH Jesus can happen even though Jesus was begotten.&nbsp;4. Who is the beloved? Is it Jesus?&gt;&gt; Yes; see eph 1:85. What was intended to receive the praise discussed here?&gt;&gt; His glorious grace6. What events or actions were leading to the praise discussed here? (Options from Eph 1:5)... maybe: purpose of his will... maybe: adoption as sons through Jesus Christ... maybe: he predestined us... maybe: In love he acted-- In any case, the action (I.e., the one that brought the praise to his glorious Grace) caused blessings IN the Beloved, Christ.&nbsp;-- Isaiah 43:21: God blesses and cares for the people he formed for himself SO THAT they will bring Him praise.-- Isaiah 61:1-3,11: God grants freedom and deliverance and comfort and gladness SO THAT he will be glorified.-- Jesus died to purchase righteousness and life! This is the reason The Father loves the son.7. Is "blessed (χαριτόω charitoō) in the beloved" is a reference back to "adoption as sons through Jesus Christ."?... I.e., what was the blessing?-- Romans 5:15-17. The free (charisma, and dorea) gift is righteousness that comes through an abundance of grace.&nbsp;-- Ephesians 1:13. The Holy Spirit is another gift, the guarantee of their inheritance.-- Colossians 1:13. The Father has transferred us from &nbsp;the DOMAIN OF DARKNESS to the kingdom of his agape beloved Son!-- 1 Timothy 1:13-14. Grace overflows bringing faith and love.-- 1 Peter 2:9-10. We were not a people in the dark, and had received no mercy; but now we ARE a people, and not only a nation but a priesthood. And that is so we can proclaim the wonders of Him who brings us marvelous light!-- Ephesians 1:7. Redemption through his blood. Forgiveness of trespasses.&nbsp;&gt;&gt;&gt; The blessings of being adopted and made IN Christ are numerous: forgiveness, righteousness, citizenship, a job, marvelous light, mercy, faith and love, TRANSFER from darkness, escape from the enemy kingdom, redemption from slavery, the right to proclaim God's goodness.8. Is the purpose of saying "to the praise of his glorious grace with which he has blessed..." is intended to establish that the glorious grace was integral in either the adoption, or to the predestining?-- my best guess: the grace was integral in the adoption as sons-- my best guess: the praise is triggered by his purpose, and his will, and his love, and his action of predestining us for adoption.&gt;&gt;&gt; therefore whatever it means to be "predestined as sons for adoption" it must also bring "praise to his glorious grace".9. Are we blessed WITH praise, or blessed WITH grace? And if grace, what does it mean to be blessed WITH grace (charis)?-- Philippians 3:9. We have a righteousness, and a share in His sufferings.&nbsp;-- 1 Peter 2:5. We are like living stones building a spiritual house, to be a holy priesthood to offer acceptable-to-God spiritual sacrifices.&nbsp;-- Romans 3:22,26. We are justified to have righteousness of God, and that comes through faith in Jesus.-- Romans 8:1. There is no condemnation to those IN Christ.-- Could it be the praise we're blessed with? Although God's people will be attractive (Philippians 2:15 shine like stars, Daniel 12:3; Matthew 13:43 righteous will shine like the sun) that's probably not the main point here.&gt;&gt; It seems most likely that the WITH refers to grace that brings pardon.10. Why is the grace itself praiseworthy, and not God himself?-- 2 Corinthians 4:15. As grace extends to more and more people, that increases thanksgiving, and that brings glory to God.&nbsp;-- 1 Timothy 1:13-14. Grace overflows with faith and love.-- Grace is like a beautiful river flowing from a mountain; we are blessed by drinking it and irrigating with it, and our hearts are drawn back to the source of the stream. The river flows with faith, and love, and it floods our land; and we know the mountain is even more beautiful.&nbsp;11. Whatever is the the praise of his Glorious Grace here:...in Ephesians 1:12, the first to hope would be to the praise of his Glory...in Ephesians 1:14, your hearing and believing and sealing with the Holy Spirit is to the praise of his Glory...so is there something essentially in common about the three praiseworthy things?&gt; hearing and believing and hoping and sealing and adopting and predestining are all part of the same package12. What is the difference between "blessed IN The Beloved" here and "adoption as sons THROUGH Jesus Christ"?-- blessedness isn't as powerful as adoption.&nbsp;&gt;&gt; see 3.&nbsp;13. What's the significance of calling Jesus the beloved (ἀγαπάω agapaō)? Why not the title Christ again, or the pronoun "him"?-- it helps answer the question of the object of love in Ephesians 1:4-- it connects to Jesus' baptism, where he was called the beloved son, in whom God was well pleased. Matthew 3:17.-- it becomes a name of Jesus.-- John 3:35. God's love of the Son is linked with Jesus' authority and ownership of all things.-- John 10:17. The reason that God loves the Son: because the son willingly lays down his life.14. When and how did God begin planning for his praise?-- before the age began-- before foundation of the world-- God is strategic!&gt;&gt; God had general objectives, specific plans, specific actions, to accomplish this end: praise of his glorious grace.15. Do I learn something about my need to plan and be strategic for God's glory?&gt;&gt;&gt; APPLICATION. God has planned, had general desires, specific stated goals, specific actions for His plan. It was the way he worked from BEFORE THE DAWN OF TIME. I only have a few years to live on earth: how is my planning going? What are my stated, explicit goals? What are my concrete actions? What steps am I taking to ensure my efforts auger to the PRAISE OF HIS GLORIOUS GRACE and not some other prestige for myself?

author: neal
title: i think i might be closet white trash
post_content: "The Bad Seed," my thesis film for my film and new media minor, is now in its fourth semester. It has hardly been a quick project. Unlike "felt," which was written, shot and edited in less than a month (although it had been conceived at least a year before being produced), "The Bad Seed" will probably be just shy of two years when it is completed.Part of this was in how it got started. I wrote the script back in October 2003, the semester I enrolled in an independent study film production course. Getting started was a major problem, as every time the project seemed to be getting momentum, something would come up and derail it.The project just never would have happened at all if not for the people I've been working with. I first approached Lee Willet about playing the Bad Seed, who was then just known as "the villain." I knew Lee from a broadcasting class the year before. I knew he had a lot of acting experience, I knew he had a steadily flowing imagination and he just seemed like he'd be a lot of fun to work with. Joe Erdkamp, who plays The Samaritan, was basically my only option for the hero. Joe is huge and gets mistaken for The Rock - so he's obviously perfect physically to play a superhero - but like Lee, he had experience acting and just had the perfect attitude and imagination to help me figure out the movie.Rounding out the list is Scott Eastman, who I guess could be considered art director.  I knew roughly what I was looking for as far as the basics of costumes and whatnot, but once Scott cut loose, he put together far cooler costumes than I imagined using the most mundane things. The costumes are kind of like sculptures, I suppose - he's making interesting things out of materials that really have no business being used that way.Anyway, brainstorming and bouncing ideas and receiving ideas from these three has been a more educational and helpful experience than I could really put into words. When I first got the idea for this movie, I was really excited about it and thought it was a cool story, but it would be nothing like what it's going to be without the hard work and the input of these guys. Obviously you don't have a movie if you don't have the main actors, but this movie would never have been started if not for the persistence of these guys, making me get my act together.It hasn't been easy. The first shoot, during which more than 20 people donated 3-4 hours of their time, was almost a complete waste. The main camera malfunctioned and none of the footage was salvageable. A behind-the-scenes camera caught a good portion of the action, and pieces of that will be used, but nowhere near the extent I hoped for when visualizing that first scene.The story revolves around four main scenes - the first one I just mentioned, an indoor scene in the Bad Seed's apartment, a second fight scene and then the grand finale. One of our group brainstorming sessions spawned the idea of fleshing out some more backstory, adding a flashback scene as well.In some ways, it was getting to be too big, but different ways of approaching what needed to be shot were making it surprisingly manageable. It's hard to really give examples without giving away parts of the movie, but I can say that there are going to be aspects of this movie beyond the cast and costumes that will look really high-budget, except the casual viewer hopefully won't even notice them as special effects.Well Joe decided, after years of thinking about it, to finally move to California. And that gave us a deadline to shoot the rest of Joe's parts. So yesterday, we started about 3:00 and shot til around midnight, getting pieces of the first scene, pieces of the final scene, and pieces of the flashback. It's going to be amazing if the editing actually works out and everything pieces together just right.Shooting last night, I was thinking about how probably the best part of this, beyond just getting to hang out with these people and make something with them, was watching the ideas and the project evolve with everyone's input. "Felt" was a fun movie to make, but you don't learn a lot from working with puppets and Josh Harrison's right hand.

author: MPB
title: CNN does a CBS?
post_content: As suspected, Eason Jordan has resigned. According to a Fox article, "CNN's global newsgathering infrastructure is chiefly the result of Jordan's work". What a shame to jeopardize that. Apparently there is a video of his comments, taken by the Davos Forum people; but no one can see it. Some wonder why Jordan would resign, claiming his words were misinterpretted, before anyone could view the tape and make an informed decision, potentially to his benefit. The WaPo is refreshingly upfront about the blog role in Jordan's rapid demise, stating it directly in the second paragraph of a long, 15 paragraph story:Even as he said he had misspoken at an international conference in suggesting that coalition troops had "targeted" a dozen journalists and insisted he never believed that, Jordan was being pounded hourly by bloggers, liberal as well as conservatives, who provided the rocket fuel for a story that otherwise might have fizzled.Ha! Wonder why it "otherwise might have fizzled"; maybe because the journalists who should have jumped on the story would have ignored it? Only if they were liberal and agreed with Jordan, I suppose. Suffice to say there has been ample reporting on this from the blogs, which don't suffer the same occupational lethargy. Hugh Hewitt has been at the forefront of this expose, and still is. More good examples here and here. In a classic case of poetic justice, or perhaps devine retribution, the CNN website carries the Jordan resignation story under Entertainment news. No kidding.

F. Côté12/12 qbdpThe proprietors of this hotel (which has remarkably thin walls!) brag about two historical features: First, that the Cambridge Hotel was the "Original Home of Pie a la Mode" (interesting to think that the original idea of adding a scoop of ice cream to a slice of pie somehow bears celebration); second, that this is one of the last "railroad hotels" (though, a brief search quickly uncovers quite a few).Geof Huth, "fLoor" (11 Feb 2005)un violon d'ingres

author: Mo
title: The Commute
post_content: Finally got around to reading "The Da Vinci Code".. a bit late, but hey.. I was busy reading other books..*if you're planning on reading it, then the rest of this post might be a slight spoiler*Good book, interesting premise, annoying storyline.. the ideas in the book were new to me, to be honest.. I always percieved the "Holy Grail" to be a wooden cup of Jesus, like in Indy Jones.. you know, the one where it ends in the dumb Nazis going for the craziest chalice with the most bling and end up dying and shit..Anyway, that's besides the point.. what I wanted to go on about today was more than just the concept of the "chalice" or the "grail" as stated in the book.. all that historical relic stuff was all interesting and fitted well in the framework of the story (which I found annoyingly stop/start, as though the author intended to make the job of the screenplay writer a lot easier when importing it onto the big screen).. what struck me most was the book's insight into the symbolism and ideas of "the sacred feminine"..Makes you stop and think, don't it? Jesus had a wife and kids? The Da Vinci painting of "the last supper" showing his wife, Mary Magdalene, sitting next to him on the table along with all the other apostles? Now, I'm a muslim myself so I'm not taking this in any religious aspect, simply commenting on what I've read and seen as a human being. Might be simplistic, might be wrong or skewed.. but I don't want a shitload of comments delving into religious or moral issues.. this is a simple blog written by a simple man who's talking about a simple idea..Men and women complementing each other.The belief present in males that they can control the destiny of the human race unassisted is quite unfortunate. Males tend to be physically stronger, tend to be more aggressive in nature. Taking that as a whole and looking at the current political and cultural climate in the world, you can see a dangerous route of destruction and bloodshed ahead. Political ideologies at war, and who are the politicans in the highest echelons of power? Men. Religions at war, and who are the clerics, priests and rabbis with the most influence? Men.It seems that without the counterbalance of the female, male ego and ambition for power can run unchecked and lead the whole race to self-destruction. If females dominated the world in the exact reverse situation, the world would be going to shit for reasons I can't even begin to fathom. The whole system is fucked if power and control lay in the hands of one sex.Unfortunately, current cultural and religious beliefs tend to predominantely state that women are an inferior sex, and must be treated as such. Even in the so-called "civilized world", women are still struggling for their full rights. Granted, they might have their basic rights given back to them as opposed to places like Saudi Arabia where they are treated like glorified animals.. but that touches on my main point: Why is it that men are GIVING women those rights? Its less a case of giving than giving BACK. How come those rights were taken away to begin with; and why and when did this happen? When did the yang decide to dispose of the yin and run the show? Doesn't it know that without its other half it no longer represents a whole circle, instead it just looks like a stupid piece of turd?My questions are simply a matter of observation, a matter of logic.Alright, back to work for me. Maybe next time I'll write about the state of my freezer or something more docile. All this thinking makes my head hurt.

author: Morgan
title: Introduction
post_content: This has been a great semester and I am glad that I did not chicken out, dropping yet another class because I am a total pansy. I really enjoyed writing many of the papers--the research assignment evoking some pretty strong feelings and allowing me to vent a little. I love being creative and writing what I feel, and this is where I hope to take my writing. Literature is great and all, and I love critiquing different novels and stories, but I really love writing about things that spark my fire like talk shows, society, the future, and history. Arguing has always been my strong suit, so I guess I should take some sort of persuasive or argumentation course to further develop my ideas and strategies (I have heard about the argumentation IGETC course on campus—no way). I know that I tended to be one heck of a pessimistic person all semester, but I really do have a passion for life and I really do love talk shows and some reality TV (surprise, surprise!). As Jerry Springer leaves with a final thought, so will I: English isn’t bad once it’s over. Sure it was hard, but it was fun. I am really proud of everything I have written and look forward to more research papers—not!

author: foiegras
title: Good Boys go to Heaven, Bad Boys go to Amsterdam
post_content: Washington D.C. - My new #1 restaurant. World class dining in every dimension. Reservations and jacket required. There were two options the night I dined, a 3 or a 5 course prix fixe. I chose the 3 course at $85. The 5 course was only available for parties of 2 or more at $150. I also had an excellent bottle of German Spatlese Riesling for $60. The muse was a vegetable shooter, which was much better than I anticipated given its description. For the first course, I picked foie gras two ways. (Imagine that:-) One of the two ways was foie gras soup in a shot glass with a straw. Unusual serving method, and delicious at the same time. The second way was served more traditionally on the same plate. For the second and main course, I chose the recommended Dorade, a fish, with skin on, which typically I would strip off, but it was of such find preparation that I did not need to. For the final desert course, I chose a rhubarb pastry. The rhubarb had been blanched, removing much of it's tartness but preserving it's unique flavor. Additonally, a finally plate was brought with a few small desert items on it that I could not finish. All in all a spectacular evening.

Really, I really do feel like crap, I have that weird tingling feeling in your hands which is a sign of becoming sick.  You know, it just feels like one of those really dull/not the way you wanted it to go week.  Trupixel is exploding in my face and I should'nt be mad because I can't make people be commited.  Then I have Sears, ARRRRRRRRRRRRG.  "SEARS."  I joined for the stupidest and most selfish of reasons, but I'm glad it's almost over. The song I'm listeing to, its called Grand Central, its making me think right now.  I guess its telling me to wake up, and just keep on experiencing more experiences in life.  Just to do random things, and meet random people, perhaps even find a special girl lol...I think I'll wait for university for that to happen.  Right now I guess, I'll just anticipate whats going to happen the next day.  While I was writing my outline for my Ryerson Portfolio, I was bummed for ideas.  But then I was inspired lol. author: S P
title: CCC's Liturgy for Baptism
post_content: We've begun the discussion about linking up with our friends at Crossroads Church to become a part of their larger congregation.  Our group would still function as a small Christian community, but as a part of their fellowship.  This past year and a half has been so great, and I know that with this new support and broader fellowship that the pieces will be in place for us to continue to serve our neighbors and those around us in this community.  Nothing has been decided or finalized yet, but the winds of change are blowing.  Our trust is that those winds are indeed the Holy Spirit.

author: 70th_week
title: Religion and Politics
post_content: The dishonesty and deceit going on in the political arena today is beyond belief.I’d like to recommend re-instituting the old fashioned system of dueling. In the old days, if you defamed someone you were summoned to the field of honor to back your accusations with a pistol or sword. A person’s honor and his pledged word were thought to be sacred. If someone could not be trusted, they were consideredworthless, so it was a killing matter to defame anyone publicly. I can think of a couple of Senators who should be called out by President Bush. Six shooters at twenty paces. People would be a little more careful about what they say publicly and the Republicans would gain a few seats in the Senate.

author: Dan
title: Papalbility
post_content: The cornerstone of a free and democratic society is the guarantee of the freedom to express one's self without fear of governmental intrusion or reprisal. So basic is this belief, the Framers of our Constitution made it crystal clear, via the First Amendment, that the freedoms of speech, religion, the press and association were not to be compromised by governmental intervention or legislation. Or so they thought. The clarity they intended has evolved into a murky swamp beset with lawsuits and court decisions which confuse any attempt at reasoned analysis of the issue.An absolutist would contend that all speech should be protected to preserve the right of the citizenry to project their ideas and opinions into the arena of debate. While the thought of censoring pure speech-political speech-is despicable, not all speech should share the same protection and certain limits on speech are necessary to preserve order in society. Three forms of speech are not protected by the First Amendment. Obscenity, deals with expression that appeal to the prurient interests and has no social or redeeming value. The "fighting words" or those words that arouse a passion in an individual where imminent danger or violence is at hand. And defamation, where an individual is libeled or slandered. But agreement on the elements that constitute each of these is not set in stone.One of the least protected areas of free speech is that which involves public broadcasting. While federal statutes prohibit any form of censorship in television and radio programming prior to a broadcast, Congress and the courts have awarded the Federal Communications Commission the authority to determine what is "indecent" as broadcast and effectively suppressed expression. Once placed on notice that a broadcast is deemed "indecent", the broadcaster faces fines or a notation in their file that may weigh heavily on their attempt to renew their license. A subtle form of censorship so expressly forbidden under the law?But what constitutes the moniker of "indecent"? The Supreme Court held that the term applies to the "nonconformance to the accepted standards of morality". In this day and age, what is the accepted standards of morality? The present administration has set its own standard on everything from abortion to gay marriages. Even children's shows such as Barney and SpongeBob Squarepants have taken hits from the moral right who attempts to save us from ourselves. For a governmental agency to have such power as to subjectively conclude what is decent or not flies in the face of what freedom of expression actually means.A Supreme Court decision, FCC v. Pacifica Foundation, 438 U.S. 726 (1978) upheld the superfluous powers of the FCC. A monologue by George Carlin, a famous and talented satirist and comedian, entitled "Dirty Words" ("7 Dirty Words") was aired on a radio station out of New York in the early afternoon hours. A man driving in his car with his son heard the broadcast and complained to the FCC that this was not the kind of programming that he and his son should not be subjected to this type of indecency. The FCC sent a letter of complaint to the station and though not sanctioning the station advised that further complaints would be taken under advisement once renewal of the license of the station was at hand.A brief summation: Obscenity not at issue. Indecency at issue. Children involved. Afternoon when children are present. FCC can determine what you can or can not hear. No censorship. Captive audience. This was the opinion of the majority. You read the dissenting opinions and you decide who has the most reasoned analysis. Note while you do, that the monologue is only 12 minutes long and that the adult driving the car presumably had the capacity to hit another button. As an aside, the complaint by the dad in the Carlin case was the only complaint received.Each morning on my way to work, I listen to a radio program, The Bob and Tom Show. Very entertaining, contemporary and at times promote debate on current issues through their satirical offerings. Not really for the timid or weak of heart. When my children were younger, we listened to the program while in the car together. Many times we laughed until we cried. If there was a question concerning what was said, I never shied away from an explanation. When I participated in the carpool and the backseat was filled with giggly little high school girls, I controlled the on/off switch. There was no captive audience who after listening to something for five minutes, then makes a moral decision to use their finger to find another channel.But station owners have become hesitant to air programming that may run afoul of the FCC guidelines, whether real or imagined censure would be forthcoming. While we can't call FCC actions truly censorship, the words of a Supreme Court Justice ring in my ears. "I know it, when I see it"

author: lab
title: Summer holidays
post_content: Hi, well it has been awhile but here I am again. A little more about me and Evan's Creek. I think I talked about the toung oil tree  in the yard last time. There was swing hanging from one of the limbs and I loved to be pushed as high as it would go.The tree had big leaves in the summerbut in the winter it was bare. My family was a big one there were many days when the tree was full of children. My grand mother had nine children as well as rasing me from the age of two. From the time  I was old enough to remember on sundays the house and yard was filled with sounds of many people. My Grand Mother would cook chicken gumbo, potato salad, pot roast, corn, beans of some kind and a dessert.All of her children would come after church with their families and we would  eat laugh and play the rest of the day. This is the way it was with most people in Evan's Creek families would get together after church on sundays. Stay tuned more later.

author: Mr. Thinkology
title: What Really Matters?
post_content: What is the meaning of life? Or to put it a little differently, what gives life meaning? Is there some one (or more than one) good such that if we have it, our lives have meaning and if we don't, they don't? And is a meaningful life necessarily one worth living? Is the standard for meaning wholly external or at least partially internal (is it partially up to us or not)?

author: NonBlonde
title: Bitchin' Babes...
post_content: Okay... so it's 11:46 May 15, 2004. I am so exhausted from work. I had to be at Hannaford for 8 - 1:30 came home rested actually took a nap. Then up an at it again to Dairy Queen 6 - 10. Moppin' floors sucks so much my arm is like goin' to rip off. Mcas is next week I am so not happy about that. I can't take test for the life of me.. I'm just horrible at it. But I hope I will be able to get into the Charter School. I know it will be so much better for me .. but no one else seems to think the same. My school is cool an shit I have met alot of kick ass people there but I just don't do well what so ever. I need like 1 on 1 help ya know. So I barely like hang out with anyone since I have the two jobs which sucks. My body like is havin' a hard time functionin' cause I am so weak. The reason why I have both is because I have bills up the ass to pay for. My car is like the biggest so far. I just need to take a moment to breathe or scream .... Every second of the day theres always something to do or on my mind. It's so aggravatin' when you feel like theres no self control what so ever. I try to make time for friends but mostly SLEEP...!! Which I should be doin' now but I have a hard time doin' it. I am listenin' to the new Hanson cd pretty good I must say. This is like my favorite time of night.. It's where I can just relax not have to worry about a god damn thing. When I hear certain songs I start to remember certain things.. certain person I should say. Somebody I really need to just get over. It's so hard cause I miss him so much he really did hurt me... but doesn't know how much I truly cared. It sucks when you just try to move on but knowin' that they will haunt you forever. I guess all I can do is think about somethin' else. Let's see I am sorta gettin' along with my cousins which is good we talk alot now. I guess all three of us are finally growin' out. Passin' the true immature stages that we all went through cause I remember we would always yell an scream at one another. Now we can actually conversate. I really do miss my family... My grandma an little cousin will be here in two weeks... so my mom is fixin' up the whole basement.. I might move down there later this year. I will be 18 how I wish I could get a place of my own. But for now I just need to concentrate at whats at hand all the problems I need to prioritize my life... Ya I am going to a therapist dude... It's all good hey they are going to help me straighten everything out right?!! Goin' to go crash into my bed talk to ya later man..

author: Melina Mellor
title: Being Alright
post_content: In a moment of weakness, I loose myself.  And, thank God my girlfriends are there to pick me right up off the floor and remind me of my worth.  Is it possible to be so connected to someone you've never met?  I told him this the first time we spoke on the phone.  His smell, his lips, his hands all over my body... it's these things I've turned into crack racing through my veins.  This is not love, yet.  This is disappearing in those moments and hording this delicious distraction so intensely, I'm frozen.  This, is his kiss.  Where do I vanish to in this glow of oxytocin?  I know I'm gone and I just don't want to do anything about it.  Will he call?  When?  WHEN!?  And, I feel ridiculous for even having this internal conversation with myself...on paper for Godsakes.  What do I really want anyway?  I want there to be a man so intense, so under my skin, I, and the world just fall away.  And yet, this is exactly what I don't want.  To be lost in a sea of boy.  They leave.  They find a reason to leave.  Or I will.  The distraction will make life so unbelievably unbearable I will have to go.  I will fade into a fog of emotional torment and then be sick.  This was just supposed to be sex.  Fun.  Brief.  Then, someone started to feel.  Someone started to notice this was good and ruined everything.  But, my girlfriends.  Help me dear girls.  Remind me of my worth.  Remind me of my value and my happiness and my dreams.  And tell me I am not lost.  I'm just lost in love.

author: Kira
title: Hint, hint?!
post_content: I was just realizing how life throws us the funniest situations. I guess "life" can't really throw anything; ok, rephrase "God allows funny things to happen." For example: I auditioned for one acts last night. Miss Big-Head Theatre Junkie was not worried about getting into a show but when i first looked this morning, five of the nine had been posted and i had not been cast. Maybe i'm not such a big shot after all! However, when i looked at lunch, I had been cast as "Mabel" the ditzy girlfriend. Now this is the funny part. My boyfriend "the repairman" is none other than the guy my dearest cousin dated last year, the guy who thinks that I "shot him mean looks" and "hate". First of all, that is completely bogus. I do not hate anyone and i can assure you that if he thinks that i shoot mean looks then all my looks must be mean because i do NOT alter the expression on my face when i see him. Ha. I have no idea what my role is going to be like, aside from the fact that my character was described as overly optimistic. Does anyone else notice that i don't EVER the role of a normal human being? I love it! I wouldn't want to play those anyway. I actually avoided auditioning for the serious shows, something i've never done before. So yeah, i'll be playing the girlfriend of my cousin's former boyfriend. This is bound to be exciting. I also realized that it's rather humorous that i refused to read the love advice book my mother brought home for me yesterday when just a few days ago i said that i was going to write my own love advice book. Maybe the author of "Stupid Things...etc etc" just wanted to vent off some steam about love gone amock too. However i still will not read her book, despite the fact that it's supposed to be really good, a best seller, blah blah blah. Lady, i've had enough advice given to me that i could sit and write a book myself. Yes, life is full of humor if we only take the time to sit and think about it.

author: drwelts
title: Uncertainty...
post_content: Christmas starts before Halloween and gains a kind of destructive force and speed like some monstrous snowball hurtling down a mountain.There is no denying it. It is on TV. It is on the radio. It is outside your window. It is at your job. It is in your dreams. It is under your bed. It is at the tollbooth on the turnpike. It is in the men's room at the Dakota. It is ubiquitous. The music never stops. You're OK at first but even those with relatively good mental health are eventually reminded of or re-live every minor and major disappointment of some previous Christmas or every loss associated with a special person no longer with us. If one Christmas carol doesn't get you another one eventually does. There is no escape. Resistance is futile. You will be assimilated. There is no escape from Christmas. You will never have enough money to deal with it. You will never be broke enough to be removed from it. You will never be able to hide from it. Christmas is all around you.You will not make new Christmas memories with the exception of particularly nasty December events, like a terrorist attack or a newly discovered attempted genocide somewhere in some country whose name you cannot pronounce. Peace on Earth- fat chance- good will towards men- no comment...and you haven't even considered the New Year yet...

author: Patrick
title: So this is what it's all come down to...
post_content: As I sit here I still can not really believe what I witnessed on TV. I just saw the last "Call For Help" on Tech TV. Now I know what I last wrote about concerning change, and let me state that my position on change has not "changed". That having been said, I see this change as sad, mainly because I don't believe taking Call For Help off the air was a wise move. Now before I go further let me state here and now that I have never worked in TV. So I don't understand all that goes into these types of decisions. HOWEVER, I have watched many hours of television in my life and I know what I like and what others have told me they like. I think that if G4TechTV is to survive, it needs to bring together the best of both networks. That also means providing programming for a wider number of people. Call for Help was of great help to the newbie computer user as well as helping those more advanced with problems that we just can not seem to get our head around. Now that the new owners have seen fit to remove that help, I wonder how many devotees of the show will not stick around to see the new network. If they don't, that will be a loss not only to them but to the new network.  OK enough of the missed opportunity segment. What I really wanted to say is "thank you to everyone who brought us Call For Help!" I hope that you all know how much you have helped us all over the years. I would start calling names but then I would forget someone and I do not want to do that. You all touched our lives in many ways from keeping us in touch with one another and our families to making sure these "personal confusers" do not get the best of us. You showed us cool websites and where to get free stuff. You taught us how to take better pictures and how to fix our little mishaps behind camera and on the keyboard. We called you to get us through the scrapes we got ourselves into and you were always there with answers. Personally though, you gave me the courage at 37 to pick a new career path for my second career. I am currently going back to school so I can start a job in the movie and gaming industry. It is ironic that I start down this new path that you helped me pick just as you are taken off the air. I wanted you all to know however that you all had a part in showing me that I can do take this path. Thank you all so much for all you have done.

author: Janos
title: The Adventures of a Gym Rat
post_content: Nipple Burn.  Yes, nipple burn, this is what I want to talk about.  Around a week ago I went to the gym and wore this soccer jersey that I have and (much to my dismay) the material from the shirt gave me fabric burn right on my nipples.  And it was not comfortable.  Seriously, this is unpleasant experience and the silence needs to be broken.  Things worsened today when I wore a different shirt to the gym and the combination of the material, sweat and running actually caused bleeding.  It soaked through my shirt and made me abort my stretching session out of panic.  I wasn't so freaked out about people noticing, I was worried about what I may have actually done to a sensitive part of the human body.  There was a moment when I actually pictured a mangled nipple staring back at me for the rest of my life.  What did people do when polyester was the norm?  Did they just live through the pain?  Why can't all clothes be really soft?  Is this not something that we should be striving for as a society, not just equality amongst people and balanced existence with the planet, but also really soft clothing.  Seriously think about it.  Wouldn't you like to be swaddled in soft cotton and in slippers throughout the day?  We would all know what it Hugh Hefner lives like but without the selling of women's bodies on our consciousness.

author: teenymeany
title: Damn Americans
post_content: So here I am in Paris! Yes, its one week here and then a few days in Belgium for me. I have been strangely relaxed here considering I dont speak French well and I dont know my way around. But I groove with the rythym of city life - its nice to depend on public transportation and to walk. People have been very nice, so far I have not met one stereotypical scornful French person, everyone has been so nice to me and actually apologetic. Yesterday I walked around the Latin Quarter taking in Notre Dame, the Louvre and Hotel De Ville. The Hotel was special to me because I used to like the famous Doisneau photograph of the couple kissing in front of it. Notre Dame and the Louvre gave me great photos. Being a tourist exhausts me so today I wanted to catch up on my favorite stores that I used to go to in NY. Funnily enough, after all that saving up for this, I found nothing that I wanted.  Oh dear, maybe I'm getting older! xoxoxo

author: White Princess
title: a ponte de mentirinha
post_content: Me integrei à Operação Cavalo de Tróia (por provocação, digamos). Visualizei setembro como sendo um bom mês. Pensei com mais e mais força na minha próxima viagem, pelo sertão do Brasil. Descobri um dos motivos principais da viagem: a última parada. Pensei NELE. Pensei NELE. Pensei NELE. Tentei fazer sexo por telefone, mas não fui bem sucedida. Planejei os elementos do fim de semana (chinese, ratata, dvds, jogos, dark room, terapia). Não trabalhei. Sonhei com um começo bem antes do começo, talvez... Conversei sobre literatura russa e novelas brasileiras. Nada é, assim, por acaso, eu sei. Mas parece que todas essas coisas não existem de fato. Parece que agora o mundo pra mim é um eterno olhar no relógio. Uma eterna espera. Nada me satisfaz. Estou no trabalho querendo ir logo pra casa. Estou em casa querendo ir logo pro trabalho. Cadmia nem pensar. Um cigarro atrás do outro. Tudo é chato, chato, chato. Depois de perder ilusões, agora estou tentando buscar outras. Mais sublimes, talvez. Só uma coisa me interessa de verdade, só um assunto me anima. E até o livro veio com essa agora: The Key Open The Past. I HOPE. Vou ali, ficar esperando, então. A noite vai ser boa, pelo menos. Se alguma coisa acontecer, eu posto de verdade. Como todo o resto agora, isso aqui é só mais uma mentira.

author: Joseph Morgan Ives
title: Blog Three - The Son of Blog
post_content: Attempt number two at a consistent blog. This time I'm not going to worry so much about trying anything specific, I am just going to use this blog as a tool to get my brain rolling every day and clear out and untangle some of the various threads that are always rattling around aimlessly in my bean.Today started with a random genealogical quest to discover something of the origins and ultimates fates of a CHARLES IVES who settled in Barbados in 1680. I was only aware of one Ives in Barbados, namely the aforementioned Charles, but it appears there were also a John, Peter, James and Urania, possibly all siblings or some variety of cousins to each other. If any Ives from Barbados end ups reading this send me a line...So now I start poking around again and already I am reshuffling my previous assumptions. Barbados is divided into parishes, and we find Charles and Peter in St. Michael, John and James are in St. Philip, Urania in Christ Church. This makes it less likely they are all one family, though anything is possible. Christ Church borders on St. Michael's parish on the south so maybe Urania is connected to Charles and Peter. Saint Philip is on the south-east tip of Barbados, Christ Church parish borders it on the west.Barbados come under English rule in 1625. I think out of all the areas that the British established plantations Barbados had the highest percentage of slaves versus free whites and so was became an unattractive destination for poor white emigrants, plus the climate and other factors contributed to a very high mortality rate for new arrivals. The majority of the white population on Barbados in the 1600s were either very wealthy planters, or the poor whites mostly indentured servants, the British small-holders being squeezed out by the large plantation estates and either emigrating to surrounding islands in the Caribbean, or to North and South Carolina, Panama, or British Guiana.Next we Have a Richard Ives emigrating to Nevis, now with Saint Kitts, The Federation of Saint Kitts and Nevis. 1620 beginning of English sovereignty. Beginning of settlement by British in 1628 by Anthony Hilton and 80 followers, plus another hundred from London. Richard Ives came to Nevis in 1654.I'll return to these at a later date.The rest of day has been spent reading Tigers in the Snow by Peter Mathiessen and Maurice Hornocker (Also heartily recommend Of Tigers and Men by Richard Ives - and any biographical information on this Richard would be appreciated). To me Peter Mathiessen and another naturalist friend of his Geroge B. Schaller have among the most interesting lives possible - roaming around the wilds of the world (or what is left of them) and observing animals. Any excuse to wander around Siberia, Mongolia or Central Asia is a good one I think. Even better if somebody funds you to do it.Also procured a couple of the new editions of the Flashman Papers by George Macdonald Fraser and a couple more in Bernard Cornwell's Sharpe's series so overall a pretty good day.

author: Aaron Baideme
title: Let Me Die Loving, and So, Never Die
post_content: Okay. I guess I definitely posted way to soon. First of all, I felt as if I lost, but in the end, Fate dealt me a royal flush. Therefore, I win. Lol. Maybe some explanation is needed.I met this guy at Village Inn named Nick. He had moved here from Cedar Rapids and had become a regular. Well, I ended up giving him my number and I got his and we sorta hooked up. We we're sorta going out as friends (or rather, acquaintances). Well, we had some late nights together (don't let your imagination take you too far with that statement). Anywho, he's bi and I kinda realized all of this, but didn't truly accept it. Well, when he's gay, I win. However, if a hot chick comes along, I lose. I guess though he's only gay when he's single, bored, and/or horny. Yea. Now he doesn't talk to me. I haven't really tried to talk to much to him, but I'd still like to remain friends. Plus, he owes me about forty bucks or so. The day I typed the "I lose" posting, was the day I officially knew it was over, but he was also planning to go back to Cedar Rapids (never to come back). Needless to say, he's still in Omaha, but I still never talk to him.Well, after Weslyan, which was loads of fun (Michael's crazy and Lily's talented at being blonde, and Joe's.... Joe), but I was covering someone's shift Saturday night. Well, I met Nate. He goes to Valley, he's really cute, he's gay, he likes me. And we've started to hang out. We also have the "psycho-path overachiever/doing-something-all-the-time" aspect in common as well. But, sadly, I'm an insomniac and he's not. Not a huge loss. Anywho, so that's cool. I guess, overall, this weekend was nice. We have school off on Thursday, Friday, and Monday so that's something to look forward to. All I have to do is survive three days (unfortunately, that includes work every night, precalc test tomorrow that im no where near ready for, french test, and a japanese presentation). Well. we'll see what happens. Until next time....-Aaron B.

author: CustomerNonService
title: Sprint Airave
post_content: Thinking about getting a Sprint Airave to enhance your coverage at home by using your Internet broad band connection?I bought one and returned it because of potential legal liability.The unit is to provide fill-in coverage by creating a micro cell site in your home or work and using your high-speed Internet connection to tie into the Sprint network.Once an Airave is activated on your account, you can -- and should -- restrict who can make calls. I restricted the Airave service to my cell phone because I'm the one paying for the high-speed Internet and I always want to insure that I have the service when I need or want it (the device can only handle three phones at once).When you restrict access, the unit, according to Page 33 of the manual, is to do this: "When unauthorized callers within range of the base station attempt to place a call, they are automatically redirected to the near cell tower."However, the unit does not work according to the manual. If Virgin Mobile and Sprint users are close enough to the Airave, their phones will lock onto the Airave and be unable to make or receive calls -- without notice.I learned this the hard way. A friend with Virgin Mobile was visiting and expecting a call. No call came. He wondered if the phone worked and tried to make a call. He got the message that he was connected to a Sprint Private Network and was told to move out of the area. A neighbor with two Sprint phones (personal and business) told me one day that her Sprint service had stopped working.The result: the neighbor blamed me, not Sprint, for interfering with her phone service.Note this language in Sprints Terms and Conditions:"You agree to indemnify, defend and hold us harmless from any claims arising out of your actions, including, but not limited to, failing to provide appropriate notices regarding location-sensitive services (see "Location Based Services" section), failure to safeguard your passwords, backup question to your shared secret question or other account information, or violating this Agreement, any applicable law or regulation or the rights of any third party."What this means:-- if a neighbor sues Sprint because of my action of buying and installing an Airave that disrupts the neighbor's service and any untoward results, I'm on the hook for all of Sprint's legal defense bills.-- if a neighbor sues me because of my action of buying and installing an Airave that disrupts the neighbor's service and any untoward results, I cannot go to Sprint for reimbursement of legal bills.Either way, just one lawsuit could wipe you out financially, whether just or not, whether it goes anywhere or not.My legal counsel advised me to terminate my Airave service to avoid liability problems. I took the advice and returned the unit.

author: Odor
title: First Multi-Engine Flight
post_content: Fastforwarding to the completion of my training...I received my DC-9 type rating in the MD90 Level D full motion simulator on April 27th, 2005.  About a week and a half later I graduated Summa Cum Laude from the program and began my quest to find a job as a professional pilot.  Many of the regional airlines are in a hiring frenzy.  All of my concerns, suspicions, and doubts are being refuted and for the first time (as far as I know) my timing has been impeccable.Just a couple days ago I interviewed with Atlantic Southeast Airlines.  They are a wholly owned subsidiary for Delta and operate as Delta Connection.  I hoped, but never really thought that I would be in a position to fly for an airline after only 250 hours of flight training.  Mind you, each one of those hours are high quality training hours and I believe that I am prepared to move on as a professional pilot.  At the same time I feel very lucky to be in my position and am delighted to have the opportunity to work for a classy operation.  Sometime this week I'll find out the results of my interview.  Secretly, as I do not want to jinx myself, I feel confident that I will get an acceptance letter and move to Atlanta to start my new life.  Until then I an going to visit my cousin after he has been in the hospital for a month from his car accident.  He is doing much better but I'll be happy to see him and the rest of the family.

title: trouble-bubble
post_content: just as i was immersed in an emo song, he had to chat me up.damn. just as i thought i could try to forget him slowly each day, he had to be online everytime i logged in.and now he's talking to me. to ME!!im hyperventilating. goddamnit.ok thing is, usually im the one who has to initiate the conversation. thats a clear sign it's a one-sided thing again, right? damnit.always happens to me. why am i not surprised.okay im over-reacting. it's just a friendly chat. oh crap. i just miss him *haha*sometimes i found myself looking at the photos we took back in school.. the library, the foodcourt, at orchard. everywhere. and then i miss him. miss them. oh shite. im at a loss of what else to talk about. see.. that's why i dont like chatting with him. coz he doesnt talk much, and so do i. *bleah* if i were to go for today's May babies celebration, i could get to see him.but my face's got rashes. so there goes the meeting. hmm... how blind of me to miss this 'great' opportunity huh. well, that's me. let this heart mend, please. *haha*-----ok abt 1 1/2 hr later, he left. to get ready, of course.he asked me twice if im going.that doesnt mean a thing, right?i wish it did.i wished really hard it would mean a thing.but i guess not. "how could this happen to me?" - Simple Plan's Untitled.*sighs*why doesnt smtg nice happen to me once, at least? im left heartbroken all the time. it's just so unfair you know.oh crapping again.anyway, we talked random stuff.everytime he mentioned 'guitar', im mesmerized.i adore (greatly) guys who play guitars. and he DOES!! *sighs longingly*how i wish he could croon me to sleep with the guitar... *haha*see how i came to talking abt him again. argh.oh. then he said i should be more open, that sometimes he finds it hard to talk to me.i replied i was at a loss for words with him too. and i think i said it wrongly, coz he took some time to reply. awkwardness.oh great. see lah, a slip of the tongue again. to think back, i did hint my feelings, and i think he should pick up the signals, but he chose to ignore it. cause it will NEVER happen, yeah?cause we're different. a whole lot different. of course i do wish i could fall for the right one.but that right one isnt right anymore. there's no more right person left. all taken. sighs. im so pathetic.that day, i dreamt of you. dreamt of you giving me a letter asking me out. and then i forgot what happened. i think i woke up.woke up to an aching feeling, of an event that wont ever happen to unlucky me. unlucky me bathed and pondered, wished hard again if there is a 1% chance you'd ask me out. but i guess not. not when we have nothing to say to each other.that's not good, right? to not have things to say. to not communicate.communication is essential in a relationship, no? so true. so so true.so does that mean i have to change myself, so that i could have a boyfriend?that's hard. very hard. and the next day, i dreamt again. of 2 guys, this time. one that i loved so deeply, the other i had no feelings. and i had to marry the no-feelings guy, my heart crumbled and hurt so bad, it felt so real. i woke up again, feeling melancholy, bathing and pondering again."was that how love is supposed to feel?" i asked myself. if so, why does my heart hurt so bad now? why do i feel like im in the brink of tears anytime? especially everytime i see you online, and you dont talk to me, it hurts.will you ever know?i am afraid. this feeling that i feel. i dont want to feel this way. never.to suffer the consequence of one-sided love/like.for now, i guess i should think of our conversations as if you felt the same way. everytime, i lie to myself, just to make me feel better.how true.

author: quintessence
title: Ode to the cloud of fire
post_content: How disappointing when a stranger unjustly overestimates its kind. Tell me, who ate your heart? You’re cold inside. Is there a discreet impression you ought to unleash? Was it despair or perhaps desertion? How long have you been tortured by passion? has it been a month? a year? all your life?Heed, stranger. I’ll take you away from all the cynics in this world. Will you? Or won’t you go with me?

author: Liz
title: One Year
post_content: Well, it's official.  I think God's wish is to just kill everyone I love dearly.  First Nate last month, then Brandon Sturdy, now my Grandma.  Man, I love her, she was such a doll.  And now she's gone.  I miss her completely with my heart.  Tonight is the visitation and I'm a little nervous.  I haven't cried yet, most likely 'cause I don't want to accept another death.  But if I don't cry at the visitation I'll prolly wonder what's wrong.  Am I out of tears?  I know I ran out of them at Boone, and have been empty of them since.  I just can't stop thinking, why are so many people dying all of a sudden?  Is God trying to tell me that it's that time to start letting things go and go into the future?  Who knows.  I'm just out of it.  In and out of reality, you might say.  *hugs* Liz

author: Najat Fares Kessler
title: 7 Steps to make an achievable 2005 Resolutions & Goals list
post_content: Published on Edge Life, Minneapolis, MinnesotaGoing back to my native Morocco after five years absence was quite an experience this past year. I left as a corporate employee, single, glamorous and ambitious and I came back a healer, not glamorous, caring much less about ambitions and much more interested in the realms of love.A group of Minnesota women and I spent time with my family, and then we visited Casablanca before heading south to Marrakech. We had the privilege to visit the biggest mosque in the world -- Hassan II Mosque -- which was built half on land and half on the sea. It is a jewel of Moroccan architecture. The first day in Marrakech, some of us visited the ancient part of the city, which is colorful, rich and abundant with merchandise of all kinds: spices, olives, almonds, pottery, brass ornaments, carpets, clothing, shoes and much more. We walked all morning and finally stopped to have lunch in a two-story restaurant on the roof overlooking the ancient place of Jamaa El Fenaa. Oh, the food was among the greatest enjoyments of the lands of Morocco. Mostly grown organicly, the food was served in much smaller portions, but it was so tasty. It was the middle of the day. The temperature was hot, yet feeling good.The following day we traveled to Essaouira, the blue and white pearl of the Moroccan Atlantic coast, the city of silver, thuia wood, where you can enjoy the fish caught early in the morning for lunch! The Festival of Gnawa Music was taking place, and the city was full of visitors and artists from all over the world. Five big stages set up in different parts of town held free and open shows. The whole city was in a magical trance and the music was playing everywhere. It almost felt like one big heartbeat, and that beat stayed with me for almost two months after I returned to Minnesota. The people were dancing in the streets and there was so much joy and happiness. I realized afterward that during this whole tour I was not afraid, nor were the women with me. In fact, they sometimes stayed outside walking and shopping all by themselves until 2 in the morning. Morocco is filled of sacred, fascinating and mystical places. However, the most sacred, powerful one that affected me the most is the kindness and the warmth of the people of Morocco. The women attending the retreat and I made wonderful connections with the people we encountered. We were helped, taken care of and overly spoiled by almost everyone: my family members, the Sufi Meditation Women's group, the hotel workers, restaurants waiters and mostly everyone we encountered! Because I am from Morocco, I am not quiet sure if I forgot or if I ever appreciated what I had when I lived there. But this trip, despite all the responsibilities I had as a retreat leader, was the most magnificient traveling experience I have ever had! -- Najat Fares Kessler, MinneapolisPublished on Edge Life on February, 2005. http://www.edgenews.com/issues/2005/02/postcard.html

author: The Righteous Sister
title: Knocking with Keys
post_content: Now, I do a lot of business with USPS. They're affordable and for the most part, they are reliable. But sometimes, they have a hint of retardism.Just my luck, I'm currently living in apartment unit 2O. That's TWO-letter O. Not twenty. I've had problems before when I was setting up our cable internet. When I called in my appointment, the technician over the phone said, "I'm not seeing your apartment... oh 2_O." It was inevitable that the USPS would make the same mistake. A few months ago, I ordered a textbook to be sent to me. After 3-4 weeks after the purchase, the seller emailed me that the book was sent back to him... stamped on the package "Return to Sender, Address Undeliverable." The 2nd attempt was successful. And now... I somehow get mail delivered correctly with only "Apt 2" on it and no O nor zero. Amazing.The Righteous Brother also received a miracle delivery. On the envelope, the street address was off... correct number but a street name that did not resemble his whatsoever. And yet, they found him correctly! How?!?!And my classic encounter at the post office a couple of years ago. I attempted to mail a book via media mail. And the clerk refused to give me media mail rate. Her exact reasons for refusing it to me:   The book is not heavy enough, and thus doesn't qualify for media mail.   The book is paperback, and only hardcover books are real books and qualify for media mail.   It only had 200 pages, and that doesn't qualify as a book.    I find it hard to believe that this worker knows what a real book looks like.  She had the most ridiculous definitions of a book. [FYI, the novel was "Beowulf"]

Maybe I really am the "get-over-and-done-with" kind of person. 先苦后甜. Haha!Anyway, one of the reasons I need my timetable to go according to plan is because of my new tuition assignments. author: Accroya
title: Drought
post_content: Took the kids to the movie theater recently. Even though I always sneak food in, I get this paranoid feeling just as I hand in my tickets, as if somehow the ticket taker is going to strip search me. So we're walking in the theater, and that feeling comes over me. Then I notice the ticket taker is a lady in a wheelchair, who had what appeared to be cerebral palsy. For a brief moment, my thought was, "Good, she won't be worried about our snacks." Immediately, I felt like the biggest jerk in the entire world. I was at that moment. I was more worried about saving a few bucks on concessions, than I was about this person who has the guts to get out there in the working world, despite a serious disability. Hell, many healthy adults don't have what it takes to get a job, and this woman did. Looking back, not only do I feel like a jerk (still!) for that brief thought, but I also feel great respect for this person. Not only that, but I learned a valuable lesson that day.
